{"timeCrawl": "05:18:00", "uri": "711260379", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T05:18:00Z", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "source": {"title": "IndiaToday.in", "uri": "indiatoday.intoday.in", "id": "930"}, "url": "http://indiatoday.intoday.in/technology/story/nokia-8-nokia-6-nokia-5-and-nokia-3-all-the-differences/1/1028458.html", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "\"The Nokia 8 is our most powerful Android smartphone,\" says HMD Global, the Finnish start-up that now owns the rights to the Nokia brand. The company has already launched three Android-based phones (and one feature phone, the revamped Nokia 3310) this year and the Nokia 8 now becomes the fourth. But unlike the Nokia 6, the Nokia 5 and the Nokia 3 that came before, the Nokia 8 is a high-end flagship phone with high-end flagship hardware specs. It also costs substantially higher than HMD's other Nokia branded phones, which isn't all that surprising, considering its hefty spec-sheet.\n\nNokia 8\n\nThe Nokia 8 is HMD's top-tier phone right now and unless the company launches something even bigger -- which now seems unlikely -- the Nokia 8 will remain its top-tier flagship phone for the year 2017. HMD and Foxconn have built it that way, after all. Unlike the Nokia 6 -- which was until now the company's most expensive Nokia phone -- the Nokia 8 looks and feels every bit a flagship phone. It may look a lot like the Nokia 6 -- when you look at it for the first time -- but make no mistake, it's nothing like it. Unlike the Nokia 6, the Nokia 8 looks and feels like a solid product that has been given ample time and effort on the drawing board. The Nokia 6 was kind of rough around the edges literally as well as figuratively. The Nokia 8 is a lot more polished.\n\nUnlike the Nokia 6 that came with sharp edges, the Nokia 8 comes with subtle curves that seamlessly wrap around the front. The front, meanwhile, is chamfered -- and comes with Corning Gorilla Glass 5 protection -- to enhance grip and ergonomics. The Nokia 8, much like the Nokia 6, is an all-metal smartphone carved out of 6000 series aluminum but two of its variants -- Polished blue and Polished copper -- have been polished to near perfection so they look like all-glass phones. They are glossy. The Tempered blue and Steel variants are meanwhile meant for someone who likes it sober.\n\nThe Nokia 8, much like the Nokia 6, has a physical home button on the front that also houses a fingerprint scanner, and is flanked by touch-based capacitive keys which are backlit. The power button and the volume rocker lie on the right, while the SIM card slot rests on the left. It comes with USB Type C port for charging and data syncing. The Nokia 8, in addition, comes with IP54 certification which makes it splash-proof (but not water-proof). It comes with an always-on display -- Glance Screen -- as well.\n\nThe Nokia 8 comes with a 5.3-inch quad-HD IPS display with 700 nits of brightness, a Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 processor clubbed with up to 6 gigs of RAM under the hood, and up to 128GB of internal storage which is further expandable by up to 256GB via a hybrid micro-SD card slot. While the Tempered blue, Steel, Polished copper variants will come with 4GB RAM and 64GB storage, the Polished blue version will come with 6GB RAM and 128GB storage. The phone is backed by a 3,090mAh battery and supports Qualcomm's Quick Charge 3.0 fast charging.\n\nAlthough the Nokia 8 doesn't ship with stereo speakers (or Dolby audio like the Nokia 6) it packs in Nokia's OZO spatial 360 degree audio technology. It comes with three microphones that allow for 360 degree spatial audio capture while recording videos.\n\nOn the camera front, the Nokia 8 comes with a dual camera system on the rear -- 13MP RGB+13MP Monochrome sensor -- assisted with Optical Image Stabilisation, laser and phase detection autofocus along with a dual-LED flash. The dual camera system has been fine tuned by Carl Zeiss. The front camera -- which is the same 13MP as the primary sensor on-board the rear -- has been given a similar treatment. This is to allow for Dual-Sight, a feature that lets a user to simultaneously use both the rear and front cameras to take stills/record videos. Think of it as picture-in-picture. If that wasn't enough, the phone also allows for live broadcast of videos shot using Dual-Sight on to social media platforms like Facebook.\n\nThe Nokia 8 has been launched at 599 Euros which roughly translates to Rs 45,000. The Nokia 8 should come to India by the end of September or early October.\n\nNokia 6\n\nThe Nokia 6 is also an all-metal smartphone carved out of 6000 series aluminum with chamfered edges and curved 2.5D Gorilla glass on the front. It has a physical home button on the front that also houses a fingerprint scanner, and is flanked by touch-based capacitive keys which are backlit. The power button and the volume rocker lie on the right, while the SIM card slot rests on the left. It comes with a standard Micro USB 2.0 port (and no USB C-Type) and also supports USB OTG.\n\nAlso Read: Nokia 6 quick review: Stellar looks, stock Android and a whole lot of nostalgia\n\nThe Nokia 6 comes with a 5.5-inch 1080p display, a Qualcomm Snapdragon 430 processor clubbed with 3GB of RAM under the hood, and 32GB of internal memory which is further expandable by up to 128GB via a micro-SD card slot. The speaker setup on-board the Nokia 6 comes with dual amplifiers and supports Dolby Atmos sound technology. The phone is backed by a 3,000mAh battery and supports fast charging.\n\nOn the camera front, the Nokia 6 comes with a 16-megapixel shooter on the back with f/2.0 aperture, Phase Detection Autofocus and dual-LED flash. The rear camera is capable of recording 1080p videos. On the front, the Nokia 6 comes with an 8-megapixel camera that's also capable of recording 1080p videos.\n\nThe Nokia 6 will be available in India exclusively via Amazon India for Rs 14,999.\n\nNokia 5\n\nThe Nokia 5 is simply a smaller, more affordable variant of the Nokia 6. The Nokia 5 -- just like the Nokia 6 -- also comes with an all-metal body and has a front-mounted fingerprint scanner. It comes with a 5.2-inch 720p display, a Qualcomm Snapdragon 430 processor clubbed with 2 gigs of RAM under the hood, and 16GB of internal memory which is further expandable by up to 128GB via a micro-SD card slot.\n\nUnlike the Nokia 6, the speaker setup on-board the Nokia 5 doesn't come with dual amplifiers and doesn't support Dolby Atmos sound technology. The phone is also backed by a 3,000mAh battery.\n\nOn the camera front, the Nokia 5 comes with a 13-megapixel shooter on the back with f/2.0 aperture, Phase Detection Autofocus and dual-LED flash. The rear camera is capable of recording 1080p videos. On the front, the Nokia 5 also comes with an 8-megapixel camera.The Nokia 3, meanwhile, will be the most affordable smartphone in Nokia's line-up.\n\nThe Nokia 5 is available in India via offline channels for Rs 12,499.\n\nNokia 3\n\nThe Nokia 3, unlike the Nokia 6 and Nokia 5, comes with an all-polycarbonate body. It also doesn't have a fingerprint scanner.\n\nThe Nokia 3 comes with a 5-inch 720p display, a quad-core MediaTek MT6737 processor clubbed with 2 gigs of RAM under the hood, and 16GB of internal memory which is further expandable by up to 128GB via a micro-SD card slot. The phone is backed by a 2,650mAh battery.\n\nAlso Read: Nokia 3 review: Nokia plus Android is a winning combination\n\nOn the camera front, the Nokia 3 comes with an 8-megapixel shooter on the back with f/2.0 aperture, autofocus and LED flash. On the front, the Nokia 3 comes with an 8-megapixel camera.\n\nThe Nokia 3 is also available in India via offline channels for Rs 9,499.\n\nNokia and pure Android\n\nAlthough in terms of specifications the Nokia phones look competent they don't exactly blow away the other phones in the market the way a Xiaomi or a Samsung or an HTC phone does. Instead, Nokia is relying on the overall experience to woo buyers. The Nokia 8, is of course, about some high-end specs and high-end features as well. That overall experience is something that the company is hoping to offer with three elements: design, the brand appeal and pure Android.\n\nOf the three, the pure Android part is the most exciting because this is something that other phones except the Motorola phones or the Google Pixel don't offer. By using clean and pure Android Nougat aka Android 7.1 in its phones Nokia is hoping to offer to consumers something that will make their smartphone experience better. At the same time, Nokia is also hoping that its design expertise will help it create phones that look different and unique in a market where almost every phones looks similar to the next one.\n\nAs for brand appeal, well, you can't deny the fact that the Nokia 8, 6, 5 and 3 are very nostalgic phones.\n\nAlso Read: Nokia 8: The good and bad about this flagship Android phone", "id": "9826718", {"timeCrawl": "08:35:00", "uri": "710770718", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:35:00Z", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "source": {"title": "IndiaToday.in", "uri": "indiatoday.intoday.in", "id": "930"}, "url": "http://indiatoday.intoday.in/technology/story/nokia-8-8-key-features-of-nokias-new-android-flagship-smartphone/1/1027768.html", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "The Nokia 8 has arrived. Ardent Nokia fans have been waiting for this day for a long time. With the Nokia 8, Nokia fans can finally look forward to a combination of the company's premium hardware with top of the line specifications and 100 percent stock Android.\n\nNokia's comeback into the smartphone game has been the stuff of legends. Nokia is a brand that is still loved and respected by millions across the globe. While Nokia 3, Nokia 5 and Nokia 6 were great smartphones, they did not show us what the new Nokia was truly capable of. The Nokia 8 though is a flagship in every sense of the word.\n\nThe Nokia 8 comes with a striking all-metal design, dual cameras at the rear with Carl Zeiss optics, OZO 360 degree audio, high-end internals, a high-resolution display and more. The smartphone, which will retail for 599 Euros, aims to challenge the big boys of the smartphone world like the iPhone 7 and Samsung Galaxy S8.\n\nNokia smartphones of old were always known for their design and build quality. With the Nokia 8, HMD Global has managed to create a smartphone that looks contemporary whilst at the same time pleasantly reminiscent of past Nokia smartphones. The precision and attention to detail are impressive. The Nokia 8 is crafted out of a single block of series 6000 aluminium and is just 7.3mm thin. Nokia claims that the device is put through a 40-stage process of machining, anodizing and polishing. Few variants also come with a high-gloss finish which takes over 20 hours to perfect.When it comes to specifications, the Nokia 8 does not disappoint. The internals are exactly what you would expect of a 2017 flagship. The smartphone is powered by Qualcomm's latest and greatest processor, the Snapdragon 835 paired with 4GB of RAM, the Adreno 540 GPU and a 3,090mAh battery with QuickCharge 3.0 support. It comes with 64GB of internal storage which can be expanded via a microSD card (of up to 256GB). Many flagship smartphones do not offer expandable storage, so brownie points to Nokia for that.The Nokia 8 comes with a unique and innovative heat management solution that prevents the Snapdragon 835 processor from overheating. It comes with a full-length graphite shielded copper cooling pipe that dissipates heat across the full length and breadth of the smartphone. Nokia claims that this allows the phone to run cool even during intensive tasks.One of the distinguishing features of Nokia's entire Android smartphone line-up is the fact that it runs on a 100 percent stock build of Android. Unlike many OEM's who heavily skin Android and fill the OS with bloat, Nokia believes in the motto - 'Pure, secure and up-to date'. The Nokia 8 runs on stock Android 7.1.1 Nougat out of the box and according to HMD Global, will be updated to Android O as and when it is released. In fact, Nokia claims that they will be amongst the first, if not the first non Google manufacturers to update their smartphones to Android O. Nokia is also promising monthly security updates for the smartphones.The Nokia 8 carries forward Nokia's proud partnership with Carl Zeiss which has given us iconic camera phones like the Nokia N95 and Lumia 1020 in the past. The Nokia 8 comes with a dual camera setup at the rear with ZEISS optics - a 13MP primary color sensor paired with a 13MP monochrome sensor. According to Nokia's claims, the secondary sensor improves low-light photography by capturing more data and also allows for the capture of depth information. The dual camera setup comes with a dual-LED flash and phase detection autofocus and can record videos in 4K resolution. On the front, there is a 13MP sensor with ZEISS optics with phase detection autofocus and a display flash.\"Be less Selfie, be more #Bothie\" - that is the marketing term used by HMD Global to sell the Nokia 8's most unique and arguably most gimmicky feature. The Nokia 8 is the first phone ever which allows 'Dual-Sight' video - video from both the front and rear camera at the same time - to be streamed natively and in real time to your social feeds such as YouTube. The Dual-Sight feature can also be used to take still pictures.The Nokia 8 has two features that will please audio enthusiasts out there. Not only does the smartphone come with a 3.5mm headphone jack- a port which is fast becoming extinct on flagships these days, it also has a feature called OZO Audio which basically allows you to capture 360 degree audio. How it works is simple -360 degree sound is captured via Nokia's acoustic algorithms along with the smartphone's three microphones. Nokia claims that binaural codecs ensure that the sound is retained even when played back on devices without OZO Audio.The Nokia 8 comes with an extremely high-resolution QuadHD display with a very high maximum brightness of 700 Nits. The display is 5.3-inches in size and comes with 2.5D Gorilla Glass 5 on top for protection against nicks and scratches. The extra resolution comes in handy while watching 2K content in apps like YouTube and also makes the phone VR ready. The Nokia 8 has been priced at 599 Euros (roughly Rs 45,500) and will go on sale globally in September. It is expected to make its way to Indian shores in the month of September itself for a price of Rs 39,999.\n\nAlso Read: Nokia 8: Specs, ZEISS dual cameras, expected India launch, price and everything {"timeCrawl": "20:03:00", "uri": "710520331", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T20:03:00Z", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "source": {"title": "Android Police - Android News, Apps, Games, Phones, Tablets", "uri": "androidpolice.com", "id": "18232"}, "url": "http://www.androidpolice.com/2017/08/16/nokia-8-official-snapdragon-835-4gb-ram-likely-not-coming-us/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "So far, HMD Global has released three Nokia-branded Android phones - the Nokia 6, 5, and 3. But the most-expensive model, the Nokia 6, still had a mid-range Snapdragon 430 processor. With HMD/Nokia's clean Android ROM and competitive pricing, many hoped for a true flagship model to be released. Now the time has come, as HMD has taken the wraps off the Nokia 8.\n\nThis phone has been in the rumor mill for months, usually referred to as the Nokia 7 or Nokia 8 in various leaks. The official site now confirms that the Nokia 8 has a Snapdragon 835 processor, 4GB of RAM, 64GB of expandable storage, and a 5.3\" 2048x1080 Gorilla Glass 5 display. The design is mostly unchanged from the Nokia 6, so if you were hoping for an edge-to-edge display or smaller bezels, I'm sorry to disappoint.\n\nAll four Nokia 8 colors, from left to right: Blue Satin, Blue Polished, Steel, and Copper\n\nThe Nokia 8 has 13MP dual back cameras, as well as a 13MP phase detection auto-focus front camera. Both are equipped with f/2.0 optics from ZEISS, who helped develop the PureView camera used on old Nokia phones (like the Nokia 808 and Lumia 1020). None of the early hands-on posts and videos contain camera samples, so we don't know how photos from the device look yet.\n\nNokia is also heavily advertising the phone's \"bothie\" functionality, which allows you to capture photos/video from the front and back camera at the same time. The name is supposed to be a combination of \"both\" and \"selfie,\" but comes across as HMD trying to be hip with the youth. You can also start live-streaming directly to Periscope and Facebook from the camera app. Finally, the Nokia 8 ships with OZO spatial 360-degree audio, so videos should sound pretty good.\n\nAs you might expect from HMD/Nokia, this phone comes with a near-stock version of Android 7.1.1 and will presumably be updated quickly. The handset was long in the rumours, but Wednesday's launch finally put an end to all those speculations about the phone and its specifications.\n\nNokia has chosen the specifications carefully so it can hold a steady ground despite competition from rivals such as Samsung and Apple. The biggest highlight of the Nokia 8 is that the phone brings back the best of Lumia days with Carl Zeiss optics.\n\nPrice and availability in India\n\nNokia 8 will be available globally in early September. It carries a price tag of EUR 599, which roughly translates to Rs. 45,000, but don't expect this to be final price when the handset arrives in India. In case you are wondering when that might happen, a company spokesperson confirmed to Gadgets360 that Nokia 8 will launch in India in early October.\n\nCamera\n\nNokia 8 features a dual camera setup at the back, which uses two 13MP RGB and monochrome sensors with f/2.0 aperture, laser autofocus and dual LED flash. Both sensors help capture pictures and fuse them together to produce a detailed image. But that's just the surface of what Nokia 8's camera is capable of.\n\nNokia 8Nokia\n\nHMD Global has added state-of-the-art technology that allows Dual-Sight video streaming on Facebook and YouTube. The company is calling this feature \"bothies\" - short for capturing selfies and videos from both cameras.\n\nNokia 8Nokia\n\nNokia 8 is also equipped with high dynamic range microphones to capture surround sound using Nokia Ozo Audio algorithms while shooting videos, which ensure quality effects even while sharing videos on social media.\n\nFor selfie lovers, there's a reliable 13MP front snapper with 4K recording support on both front and rear cameras.\n\nDesign and display\n\nNokia has picked top-of-the-line materials for the Nokia 8. The flagship is built with 6000-series aluminium and has a splash-proof IP54 rating. The handset comes in four colours, glossy Polished Copper and Polished Blue, and matte Tempered Blue and Steel, which gives a varied choice for buyers.\n\nNokia 8Nokia\n\nThe handset has been designed in such a way that users won't have heating complaints, thanks to the copper pipe solution and graphite shield to transfer heat.\n\nNokia 8Nokia\n\nMatching the requirement of a flagship smartphone, the Nokia 8 comes with a 2K resolution display measuring 5.3 inches diagonally and has a Gorilla Glass 5 for protection. The overall design of the phone is a reminiscent of existing Nokia 6.\n\nPerformance\n\nUnder the hood, Nokia 8 packs a powerful Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 chipset with 4GB RAM, 64GB expandable storage up to 256GB and a 3,090mAh battery. There's a USB Type-C port and a 3.5mm headphone jack. {"timeCrawl": "02:10:00", "uri": "710636785", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T02:10:00Z", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "source": {"title": "The Indian Express", "uri": "indianexpress.com", "id": "1155"}, "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/technology/mobile-tabs/nokia-8-first-impressions-features-dual-camera-bothie-4800268/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Written by Shruti Dhapola | Published:August 17, 2017 7:34 am Nokia 8 wlll start selling in India this October Nokia 8 launched with dual camera and ability to stream from both sides; to be available in India early OctoberNokia 8 full specifications, expected Indian price and everything else to knowNokia 8 likely to be unveiled today as HMD Global gears up for flagship launch\n\nNokia 8 is the new flagship in town, as HMD Global announced this phone at the iconic London Tower Bridge in a special event. Nokia 8's specifications and features had been leaked online extensively, and for the most part there were no surprises in the phone. However, there's the 'Bothie' in the Nokia 8, which is basically the option of using the front and rear camera at the same time to stitch together one image, video and even live stream.\n\nWe had a chance to experience the Nokia 8 extensively before the phone was officially announced, and here's our first impressions and hands-on of the Nokia 8.\n\nNokia 8 Design, Display\n\nNokia 8 sports a 5.3-inch 2K LCD IPS display and has a metal unibody design, though there are two polished colour variants of the phone, which have a glossy finish. Nokia 8 is launching in four colours: polished blue and polished copper, tempered blue and steel. The latter two have a matte finish. It seems HMD Global wasn't content with just launching black and white and gold coloured phones.\n\nFrom a design perspective, HMD Global's new flagship resembles the standard Nokia phones that we have seen in the past. There are no reduced bezels on the display, no curved edge display, which granted was not expected either. Nokia 8 has a slight curved design, which makes the phone easy to hold and use. There's also Corning Gorilla Glass 5 on the front, and a fingerprint resistant coating at the back.\n\nMade of 6000 series aluminium, this is one good looking flagship. Is this the most unique looking in the market? As far as colours go yes, and this is a pretty sleek phone. But other than that, the design of the Nokia 8 still plays it very safe.\n\nThe glossy versions of the phone are slippery, and prone to turning into smudge city very quickly. The 2K display for its part should be adequate for most users, and this is vivid and bright enough. Again we will have more on this once we have spent some time with the device.\n\nNokia 8 Specifications, Software\n\nHMD Global is clear that it is not playing the specifications war, even though this phone comes with Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 processor, which is the latest from the chipset maker. But there's no 6GB or 8GB RAM variant, instead what you get is standard 4GB RAM and 64GB storage which is expandable.\n\nDoes this lack of extra RAM put this flagship in danger of losing out to others in the market? HMD Global doesn't think so because they are convinced the lack of bloatware, coupled with their clean UI gives the phone a smooth performance. They are also confident Nokia 8 will do well in benchmark tests. Of course, we all don't need 6GB RAM on our phones. However, the lack of 128 GB variant raises some serious questions, especially since the phone's front and rear camera both support 4K video recording.\n\nSoftware wise, the clean UI of the Nokia 8 is an advantage, and the company claims this will be the fastest phone to get Android O updates as they are already in development on this. For fans of clean, stock Android, the new Nokia 8 will seem appealing.\n\nNokia 8 Camera, Audio\n\nSo HMD Global has taken the plunge into the dual-rear camera trend. The phone has a vertically stacked set of dual rear cameras (13MP Colour sensor with OIS + 13MP Mono sensor), and there's a front 13MP camera all well. Nokia 8 has PDAF, IR range finder, dual tone flash on the rear camera, and yes there's the Zeiss Optics branding as well that used to be standard on older Nokia phones.\n\nLike most other dual cameras, the Nokia 8 is capable of shooting a bokeh mode, for portrait pictures where the background is blurred. Is this 'bokeh' perfect? Based on what I saw I would say not yet. The rear camera by itself is not bad, and below are some sample shots captured with it.\n\nBut HMD Global has done something more than launch a smartphone with dual rear cameras. It's also added a new option for dual usage, where both the front and rear camera can be used at the time, for videos, pictures and live streams on Facebook and YouTube. The native camera also supports live video streaming. Nokia 8's camera also get a manual mode. Nokia 8 also comes with OZO Audio, which promises to capture and playback all ambient sound on your video.\n\nWhen it comes to the camera, Nokia 8 is packed with features. Are all of these absolutely necessarily and likely to be used by users? Perhaps not.\n\nNokia 8 First thoughts\n\nFor HMD Global, this is the first flagship phone. The phone will be available globally in September though the India availability is around early October. The pricing isn't as exorbitant as with other flagships, given the average of Euro 599. For now, the phone looks as solid as any other Nokia phone from the past. Then there are features like Dual-Sight in the camera, Ozo Audio to name a few.\n\nBut flagships aren't an easy terrain. Apple and Samsung dominate this space, and any phone commanding a premium price will have a tough competition in these two brands. Nokia for its part has great brand recall value, but in the end that won't be enough in deciding the success of the Nokia 8.\n\nFor all the latest Technology News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: {"timeCrawl": "18:47:00", "uri": "710489548", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:47:00Z", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "source": {"title": "Pocket-lint", "uri": "pocket-lint.com", "id": "3699"}, "url": "http://www.pocket-lint.com/news/137751-nokia-8-release-date-specs-and-everything-you-need-to-know-for-nokia-s-flagship", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Nokia has announced the phone that fans have been waiting for, the Nokia 8, its flagship offering in its return to the world of smartphones.\n\nNokia previously announced three Android handsets at Mobile World Congress 2017, alongside the new Nokia 3310, a retro play that appears to be more of a marketing stunt than anything else.\n\nNow things are getting serious. Here's everything you need to know about the Nokia 8.\n\nAll the Nokia Android phones start life as a block of 6000 series aluminium, and the Nokia 8 flagship is exactly the same. As with Nokia's previous Android phones, the story is very much about the care and attention that goes into creating the handset, including the anodisation and polishing needed to create the Polished Copper glossy finish.\n\nThere's no mention of waterproofing, however.\n\nThere's a front fingerprint scanner sitting between the back and recent apps touch controls, meaning that the full space of the 16:9 display is available for you to use. It might not be shifting form factor like Samsung and LG, but it's a high quality phone.\n\nThere's USB Type-C on the base and a 3.5mm headphone socket on the top.\n\nThe Nokia 8 offers a 5.3-inch display on the front, using an IPS LCD panel. This is rated at 700 nits, so it has a lot of brightness.\n\nNokia has also made the step to Quad HD, meaning a 2560 x 1440 pixel resolution, resulting in 554ppi - right up there with the sharpest of flagship phones.\n\nDriving the phone is the Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 platform with 4GB RAM and 64GB of storage, as well as microSD expansion for those who want more space. That's a flagship loadout, so should give the handset the power to handle everything with ease.\n\nThere's a 3090mAh battery from which it's claimed you'll get over a day of use, with support for Quick Charge 3.0, so if you do go flat, you should be back in the game in no time at all.\n\nNokia has also used a liquid cooling system for the Nokia 8, with a large copper heat pipe running through the internals and a graphite heat shield to enable the SD835 to run to the best of its abilities.\n\nWhere HMD Global is looking to differentiate is in the camera. The Nokia 8 has a dual 13-megapixel camera on the rear, offering one sensor that captures RGB colour data and a second that captures monochrome data. Combining this information should lead to better quality results whatever the conditions.\n\nThe front camera is also 13-megapixels and offers the same specs, as all have an f/2.0 aperture, 1.12\u00b5m pixel size and feature phase detection autofocus.\n\nOne of the unique offerings is being able to capture from the front and rear cameras at the same time, with the ability to stream these live to Facebook or YouTube.\n\nThere's no wide angle or zoom offering, instead this is all about quality.\n\nThe Nokia 8 launches on Android 7 Nougat and is unfettered, with no bloatware and no changes from Nokia.\n\nThe only addition is a support app for owners of the phone and Nokia has used its own camera app to support the advanced functions that it offers.\n\nThere's also the ambition to bring Android O to the Nokia 8 as soon as possible.\n\nThe Nokia 8 will also be able to capture 360 audio with an Ozo Audio feature.\n\nThe Nokia 8 was announced on 16 August at a launch event in London. The Nokia will be available globally in September.\n\nThe Nokia 8 price is \u20ac599. There's no word on UK price or networks.", "id": "9544645", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Nokia 8: Release date, specs and everything you need to know for Nokia's flagship - {"timeCrawl": "22:50:00", "uri": "710581535", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T17:33:00Z", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "source": {"title": "Recombu", "uri": "recombu.com", "id": "11933"}, "url": "https://recombu.com/mobile/article/nokia-8-review-hands-on", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "The first Nokia-branded flagship smartphone under its HMD Global overlords is the Nokia 8, a 5.3-inch premium handset packing pure Android and a dual-lens camera. Our first look Nokia 8 review takes a close look at the design, performance, features and specs, as well as that 'Dual Sight' snapper.\n\nNo one can accuse HMD Global of being layabouts, that's for sure. In less than a year since they snapped up the right to use the Nokia name, we've seen the launch of several feature phones (including the nostalgia-packed 3310 reboot), plus three smartphones. Now you can add one more smartphone to that total, this time a flagship model known as the Nokia 8.\n\nThe Nokia 3, Nokia 5 and Nokia 6 were unveiled at MWC 2017, all of them affordable value-packed handsets. We certainly liked the low asking prices, yet we all clamoured for the first Nokia flagship phone in yonks. A fresh new premium blower that could rival the likes of the OnePlus 5, Samsung's Galaxy S8 and the LG G6. Now we have it.\n\nThe Nokia 8 has just launched here in Europe, to be released in September 2017. We had the chance to go hands-on for this first look review and so far we're definitely seeing the potential, although whether it can beat off attention from rivals remains to be seen.\n\nCheck out our in-depth comparisons between HMD's Nokia phones and the biggest competition:\n\nNokia 3 vs Nokia 5 vs Nokia 6\n\nNokia 8 vs Nokia 6 vs Nokia 5 vs Nokia 3\n\nNokia 8 vs OnePlus 5\n\nNokia 8 vs Galaxy S8\n\nHands-on Nokia 8 review: Specs Phone Nokia 8 Screen size 5.3-inches Screen resolution 2560x1440 Fingerprint sensor? Yes Water resistant? Splash resistant only (IP54) OS Android 7.1.1 Processor Snapdragon 835 Memory 4GB Storage 64GB microSD? Yes Battery 3080mAh Rear camera 13MP dual-lens Front camera 13MP Hands-on Nokia 8 review: Design\n\nWe love how the new HMD handsets retain that classic Nokia look and feel, while updating just enough to keep them modern and stylish. The Nokia 8 is unmistakably a Nokia mobile from the moment you pick it up, even before you turn it on and hear that distinctive four-note tone.\n\nAround the rear, a seamless aluminium backing offers a minimalist design that certainly looks sleek. The Nokia 8 is just 7.9mm at its thickest point (around the camera lens) and 7.3mm otherwise, with a curved edge for a more comfortable grip.\n\nThat said, you don't quite get an edge-to-edge finish here; those bezels above, below and to the sides of the 5.3-inch screen are a little chunky, making this Nokia flagship a similar size to the OnePlus 5. The rectangular finish is definitely reminiscent of those glorious old Lumias, although skinnier and taller. There's more than a hint of Sony Mobile about it too.\n\nBeneath the display you'll find hard back, home and recent apps buttons, built into the frame. That narrow home button doubles as a fingerprint sensor, which certainly seems responsive in our early tests.\n\nYou can pick the phone up in a matte or glossy finish, depending on your personal tastes. At launch the four choices are matte silver, matte blue, polished blue and the lovely polished copper finish. We definitely love the shiny models although they're total fingerprint magnets. Sadly there's no full waterproofing, only splash resistance with an IP54 rating.\n\nHands-on Nokia 8 review: Screen and media\n\nSo far, the 5.3-inch Quad HD display seems to be of true flagship quality. It's certainly punchy, producing vibrant visuals that stand out from the screen. Thankfully images aren't overly vibrant or saturated, so photos retain a degree of realism.\n\nBrightness levels, viewing angles and other aspects of the panel are all solid, as you'd expect at this price point. And with its 2560x1440-pixel resolution, you can expect glorious detail levels and not a hint of a pixel in sight.\n\nGot a massive media collection? The Nokia 8's 64GB of built-in storage is mostly free for your personal use, with 15GB given over to the OS and pre-installed apps. Thankfully Nokia hasn't laden the flagship phone with pointless additions, as you'll see in the next part of this review. Also, you can easily expand when needed via the microSD memory card slot, which supports up to 256GB of extra storage.\n\nHands-on Nokia 8 review: OS and features\n\nHMD is going for a 'pure, secure and up to date' version of Android OS here, as it did with the other Nokia Android phones from 2017. In other words, you can expect quite a vanilla Android experience, with no tinkering from the manufacturer.\n\nThat's something seen on few Android phones these days, which often pack an overlay that changes the look and feel of Google's OS while adding new features. Besides Google's Pixel handsets, only Motorola mobiles tend to offer a similar 'no frills' interface.\n\nAndroid 7.1.1 certainly runs smoothly on the Nokia 8, as you'd expect given the powerful specs on offer and pure OS. You get all of the usual features on tap, including split-screen multi-tasking and full resource management. Plus, an update to Android O is hopefully going to happen soon after launch.\n\nHands-on Nokia 8 review: Performance and battery life\n\nPowering the Nokia 8 is Qualcomm's Snapdragon 835, the chipset of choice for premium handsets. Not only is it more powerful than pretty much any other mobile platform right now, it's also impressively energy efficient and packs all kinds of support for smartphone cameras, security and more besides.\n\nIn our hands-on Nokia 8 session, we certainly didn't notice any kind of slowdown. Apps open instantly and browsing swiftly through the Android OS is a smooth experience. Stay tuned for our in-depth review, to find out how the handset handles everyday life and more demanding applications.\n\nThe Nokia 8 doesn't seem to heat up either, thanks to the built-in 'liquid cooling' mechanism (reminiscent of the old Lumia 950 flagship handsets). Combined with a graphite shield that disperses the heat throughout the handset, you shouldn't feel a hotspot even during heavy use.\n\nYou can charge the Nokia 8's 3080mAh battery up via Type-C USB and there's full support for Quick Charge 3.0. That should give you close to a full charge in roughly an hour. No wireless charging in sight, however.\n\nHands-on Nokia 8 review: Cameras\n\nThe camera experience is one of the features that HMD has closely considered. The Nokia 8 comes packing a 13-megapixel 'Dual Sight' mobile snapper, crafted in collaboration with optics expert Carl Zeiss (now a long-standing partnership). This dual lens juts only ever so slightly from the surface of the phone and offers some strong photography chops, continuing Nokia's focus on strong mobile camera tech.\n\nCheck out our full Nokia 8 camera preview for what we think of the flagship's shooter, as well as a closer look at the various features.\n\nHands-on Nokia 8 review: UK price and release date\n\nYou can expect the Nokia 8 to hit Europe in early September (no exact release date just yet, but stay tuned). The flagship phone costs 599 Euros SIM-free. We're still waiting on the UK pricing, although we're fairly confident you'll be paying \u00a3549 for your own slice of Nokia pie.\n\nThe Nokia 8 will not be available in the US at the time of launch, although we're expecting the phone to come to American markets early in 2018.\n\nStay tuned for our full Nokia 8 review and camera review, coming soon.", "id": "9578032", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "19:38:00", "uri": "710509681", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T19:38:00Z", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "source": {"title": "IndiaToday.in", "uri": "indiatoday.intoday.in", "id": "930"}, "url": "http://indiatoday.intoday.in/technology/story/nokia-8-launched-with-qualcomm-snapdragon-835-processor-13mp-zeiss-dual-cameras-may-come-to-india-in-september/1/1027561.html", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "After months of rumours and anticipation, Nokia 8 is finally official. HMD Global, the company behind Nokia's comeback into the smartphone game, unveiled the Nokia 8 at an event in London today. The smartphone is priced at 599 Euros and comes with an all-metal design, ZEISS optics, OZO audio and top of the line internals.\n\nTo say that the Nokia 8 is one of the most hotly anticipated smartphones of the year would be an understatement. The Nokia 8 is not only Nokia's first flagship smartphone since its Windows Phone days, it is also the first high-end smartphone from the Finnish company to run on Android.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 processor paired with 4GB of RAM, the Adreno 540 GPU and a 3090mAh battery with Quick Charge 3.0 support. The smartphone comes with 64GB of internal storage expandable via a microSD card (up to 256GB) and a fingerprint sensor embedded into the home button up front.\n\nAdditionally, The Nokia 8 comes with a 5.3-inch QuadHD display with 2.5D Gorilla Glass 5 on top for protection against nicks and scratches. The display has a maximum brightness of 700 nits and comes with Nokia's trademark Glance Screen. The smartphone also has a very innovative heat management solution with a full-length graphite shielded copper cooling pipe that dissipates heat across the full length and breadth of the smartphone.\n\nJust like the rest of Nokia's Android smartphone line-up, the Nokia 8 runs on a 100 percent stock build of Android. Unlike the Nokia 3 which ships with Android 7.0 out of the box, the Nokia 8 comes with the latest version of Android Nougat - 7.1.1. Nokia has promised that the Nokia 8 will be updated to Android O in the future.\n\nThe Nokia 8 comes with a 3.5mm headphone jack, which is fast becoming a rarity in today's world. It also comes with support for OZO Audio - thanks to Nokia's acoustic algorithms and the smartphone's three microphones, you can capture 360 degree spatial surround sound.\n\nOn the imaging front, the smartphone carries forward Nokia's proud association with Carl Zeiss which has given us iconic camera phones like the Nokia N95 and Lumia 1020 in the past. It comes with a ZEISS powered dual camera setup at the rear with a primary 13MP color sensor with optical image stabilisation and a secondary 13MP monochrome sensor. Both sensors have an aperture of f/2.0.\n\nNokia claims that the secondary sensor helps capture depth of field information and improves low-light photography. The rear camera setup comes with phase detection auto focus and a dual-LED flash and supports 4K video recording. On the front, there is a 13MP camera with an aperture of f/2.0 and phase detection autofocus for selfies.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is the first phone in the world which allows 'Dual-Sight' video to be live streamed natively and in real-time to social feeds such as Facebook. The feature allows you to use the front and rear camera at the same time for both photos and videos. Nokia calls this feature #Bothie.\n\nThe Nokia 8 has been priced at 599 Euros which roughly translates to around Rs 45,000. It will be available in four colour options - Polished Blue, Polished Copper, Tempered Blue and Steel and will go on sale globally throughout September.\n\nWhile Nokia has not officially announced details regarding the smartphone's Indian launch, it is expected to go on sale in country in the month of September itself. The Nokia 8 is expected to be priced at Rs 39,999 in India in order to compete with the OnePlus 5.\n\nBack in February, HMD Global announced the Nokia 6, Nokia 5 and Nokia 3 along with the 2017 version of the Nokia 3310. The Nokia 5 and Nokia 3 have already gone on sale in India and are available only through offline retail stores. The Nokia 6 on the other hand is available exclusively via Amazon India and is set to go on sale from August 23 onward.\n\nAlso Read: Nokia 3 review: Nokia plus Android is a winning combination", {"timeCrawl": "03:13:00", "uri": "710654340", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:13:00Z", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "source": {"title": "Firstpost", "uri": "firstpost.com", "id": "2530"}, "url": "http://www.firstpost.com/tech/news-analysis/nokia-8-launched-with-carl-zeiss-optics-bothie-camera-mode-and-snapdragon-835-for-eur-599-3939097.html", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "After months of speculations, rumours and leaks, the Nokia 8 has finally been unveiled by HMD global at an event on 16 August in London. The phone has been launched at a price of EUR 599, according to The Verge, which is approximately Rs 45,000 at the time of writing. It is rumoured that the phone will be hitting the Indian markets by October this year.\n\nImage Courtesy: Nokia\n\nThis is the first time HMD Global has partnered up with Carl Zeiss for making a smartphone. The Nokia 8 has an interesting camera setup. There are three cameras in total, the rear being a dual camera. All three use 13 MP sensors with f/2.0 lenses. The rear features an RGB sensor with optical image stabilisation (OIS) paired with a monochrome sensor without OIS. The front and rear cameras feature PDAF and the rear camera even features an IR range finder. The latter should help with improving focus speed in the dark as well as to improve depth perception for a portrait-mode-like feature.\n\nNokia is also introducing, we kid you not, a #Bothie photo mode. In this mode, you'll use the front and rear cameras to take an image or video. Better yet, it looks like you can live stream in this mode. Check out the demo below!\n\nThe Nokia 8 has 4K streaming capabilities and employs Nokia OZO Audio for spatial 360 degree audio recording. OZO is the brand name that Nokia employs for its spatial audio and VR video recording platform. This includes the OZO+ VR camera used by many Hollywood studios.\n\nHello #Bothie! The world's first smartphone to broadcast live with both cameras simultaneously. Meet the #Nokia8. pic.twitter.com/nMLl8h6YZe\n\n-- Nokia Mobile (@nokiamobile) August 16, 2017\n\nThe phone has an aluminum unibody design housing a 5.3 inch, 2K, polarized display covered with Corning gorilla Glass 5. Nokia 8 will be running on Android 7.1.1 Nougat and employs an octa-core Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 processor along with 4 GB of RAM and 64 GB of internal storage expandable to 256 GB via a micro-SD card. The phone uses a full-length copper cooling pipe with a graphite shield to dispense of heat across the metal body of the phone.\n\nThe device has a 3,090 mAh battery and 4G dual-SIM support with one slot acting as a hybrid SIM slot. It also has an IP54 rating, making it splash proof. The phone comes with a 3.5 mm jack and a type-C port (USB 3.1 Gen 1), NFC and Bluetooth 5.0 for connectivity. Bluetooth 5.0 allows for streaming audio to two other Bluetooth devices, among other things. Only a handful of phones use the feature, including the Samsung Galaxy S8 and the HTC U11.\n\nThe Nokia 8 will be available in four colours namely matte silver, polished blue, matte blue, polished copper.\n\n#Hmd global #Ip54 #Nokia 8 #Nokia 8 bothie mode #Nokia 8 camera #Nokia 8 carl zeiss #Nokia 8 features #Nokia 8 launch #Nokia 8 price #Nokia 8 specifications #Nokia ozo audio #Vr {"timeCrawl": "13:25:00", "uri": "710901512", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:25:00Z", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "source": {"title": "Neowin", "uri": "neowin.net", "id": "621"}, "url": "https://www.neowin.net/news/sony-launches-playstation-4-system-software-500-beta---here-are-the-new-features-it-brings", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369188", "body": "Last month, Sony opened registration for PlayStation 4 owners wishing to test its upcoming system software update 5.00, codenamed 'NOBUNAGA'. Today, the company is launching its beta program for that update, and said that \"if you were chosen, you'll receive an email with instructions on how to download the update and get started.\"\n\nCoinciding with the start of the beta, Sony announced details of what the 5.00 update will bring to all PS4 owners when it rolls out later this year.\n\nSony said that it's redesigning its master/sub-account system with a new Families on PlayStation Network system, which will make it easier to set up accounts for children. This will include:\n\nFamily Manager, parents/guardians and child accounts\n\nEach family on PSN will now have a Family Manager. In turn, the Family Manager can promote any other adult in the family to be a parent or guardian.\n\nFrom there, each parent or guardian can customise the parental control levels of each child account, such as restricting certain age ratings or online access.\n\nIndividual parental controls\n\nBefore this update, the same parental controls were applied to all users on the same console, including adults. But with 5.00, all controls (including game age ratings) can be individually controlled for each child account.\n\nThese are the other features and improvements that PS4 owners will have to look forward to in the 5.00 update:\n\nFriend list management\n\nIn place of the current 'Favourite Groups' tab, we're adding a new 'Custom Lists' tab on the 'Friends' screen.\n\nThis will allow you to create and edit custom lists of your friends and arrange them into specific groups, based on the games you play, or groups of friends you like to hang out with online. For example, you can create a custom list of your Destiny teammates and easily send them raid invites.\n\nBroadcast feature updates\n\nCommunities\n\nIf you've set up a community on your PS4, you can now link your community to your live gameplay broadcast. When a broadcast is linked to a community, the community button appears on the 'Live from PlayStation' spectator screen, allowing any spectator to jump directly into your community page to check out the details or join.\n\nPlayStation VR\n\nWe've added a new setting in PlayStation VR: 'Display Message to Spectators and Spectators' Comments'. Once this is enabled, spectator comments sent during a broadcast are displayed not only in cinematic mode, but also in VR mode - so you'll be able to read comments and interact with spectators from within your PS VR headset.\n\nPlayStation 4 Pro\n\nGood news for Twitch users: with this update, PS4 Pro will support 1080p 60fps streaming on Twitch.\n\nMessage improvements\n\nYou've already been able to share your favourite music to Twitter and Facebook via Spotify and PlayStation Music, but now you'll also be able to share individual tracks by sending a message on PS4.\n\nYour friends will be able to listen to the track directly from the message you send, and if they're on their mobile device, they can jump directly to their Spotify app from the PS Messages app to check out the song and add it to their own playlist.\n\nNotifications updates\n\nWe've added a new setting that allows you to disable pop-up notifications while you're watching a movie or TV show on your PS4. This setting is set to 'off' by default, so go to Settings > Notifications to enable it.\n\nFurthermore, you now have the option to turn off message previews on your pop-up notifications. If you turn this setting off, the pop-up notification will hide the message senders' online ID and will display a generic user icon and message instead.\n\nLastly, you'll have the option to change the colour of your pop-up notifications to either white (default) or black.\n\nQuick Menu updates\n\nIf you want to keep an eye out on what's happening in your Notifications tab - like game download progress or new invitations - you can now access this directly from the Quick Menu without leaving your game.\n\nAlso, we've added a 'Leave Party' option in the Quick Menu, so you can easily exit a party and go right back to playing your game.\n\nVirtual surround sound on PS VR\n\nPlayStation VR now supports 5.1ch and 7.1ch virtual surround sound through your headphones when watching Blu-rays and DVDs in Cinematic Mode, making for an even more immersive viewing experience.\n\nImproved tournaments bracket viewer\n\nWe've added a new 'bracket viewer' that shows full tournament brackets for Single Elimination and Double Elimination tournaments on PS4, making it easier for you to see the current tournament standings.\n\nIn addition to those new features and improvements, Sony is also introducing language support in the PS4 interface for Czech, Greek, Hungarian, Indonesian, Romanian, Thai, and Vietnamese.\n\nFollow us on Twitter @NeowinGaming to stay up to date with the latest gaming news and reviews.\n\nSource: Sony", "id": "9696730", "details": {"liCnt": 12}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Sony launches PlayStation 4 system software 5.00 beta - here are the new features {"timeCrawl": "22:50:00", "uri": "710581361", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T17:33:00Z", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "source": {"title": "Digital Trends", "uri": "digitaltrends.com", "id": "4329"}, "url": "https://www.digitaltrends.com/mobile/nokia-8-hmd-global/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Why it matters to you\n\nFan of Nokia phones? The brand has been revived by HMD Global, but the company's first flagship -- the Nokia 8 -- won't be available in the U.S. for you to enjoy.\n\nIt's hard to think of HMD Global as \"a startup.\" The company launched in early 2017 and skyrocketed into the spotlight due to its licensing partnership to use the Nokia brand name for its smartphones. Other than a handful of feature phones, the company launched three budget smartphones: The Nokia 3, the Nokia 5, and the Nokia 6. The latest to join the family is also HMD's first flagship smartphone -- the Nokia 8.\n\nSmartphones from HMD Global have to follow certain design guidelines from Nokia and the company works with Foxconn to manufacture its devices. A strong partnership with Google means these phones run a pure version of Android straight from Google and it also gets version and security updates much faster than any other manufacturer. With the Nokia 8, there is a rekindled partnership with Zeiss, a company known for its expertise in imaging and optics. As such, the latest Android flagship phone's special features lie in its camera application but before we dive in, let us take a look at its specifications and design.\n\nAngular design, high-end specs\n\nThe Nokia 8 looks similar to HMD Global's budget Nokia Android smartphones but not much like the Nokia Lumia days of old. There is no 2017 bezel-less design here; it looks like a standard smartphone. Its edges are curved and the screen is protected by 2.5D curved Gorilla Glass 5.\n\nThe aluminum unibody looks sleek, especially if you opt for the polished blue or polished copper colors -- they offer a \"high-gloss mirror finish.\" If the glossy look is not for you, there are two more color options: Tempered Blue and Tempered Steel. The rear also houses a vertical dual-camera setup and the Nokia brand logo in the center.\n\nThe front looks traditional, with somewhat chunky edges around the display that house the selfie camera, as well as the capacitive Android navigation buttons and the fingerprint sensor. The only buttons are on the right edge, where the volume rocker sits on the top above the power button.\n\nThe phone features a graphite-shielded cooling pipe that \"dissipates the heat\" along the full length and width of the phone.\n\nIts spec sheet is similar to other 2017 flagship smartphones. For starters, it is powered by Qualcomm's Snapdragon 835 processor and comes paired with 4GB of RAM. To ensure you get the best performance out of the Nokia 8, HMD said the phone features a graphite-shielded cooling pipe that \"dissipates the heat\" along the full length and width of the phone, making sure it will not overheat when powering intensive processing tasks.\n\nYou get 64GB of internal storage, but there is a MicroSD card slot that lets you add up to 256GB of additional storage. The 5.3-inch LCD display offers a Quad HD resolution of 2,560 x 1,440 pixels, and HMD has packed a 3,090mAh battery to keep it running for a while. It supports Qualcomm's Quick Charge 3.0 technology, meaning you can utilize the fast-charging technology via the USB Type-C port.\n\nSadly, unlike most flagship smartphones, it only has a dust- and water-resistance rating of IP54, which makes it nothing more than splashproof.\n\nLike most of HMD's Nokia phones, you will find Android 7.1.1 on the Nokia 8. The company told Digital Trends it is already working on the upcoming Android O update, which will roll out to the Nokia 8 as soon as it is ready.\n\nA camera built for live-streaming\n\nBoth the front and rear camera of the Nokia 8 feature Zeiss optics. The two rear cameras pack 13-megapixels each with f/2.0 apertures and they have specific functions. One takes photos in color and features optical image stabilization, while the other only shoots monochrome photos -- just like the Huawei P9 and P10. The front camera also has 13-megapixels, with a f/2.0 aperture.\n\nBut the killer feature is how you can live-stream to apps like Facebook Live and YouTube Live, directly from the Nokia 8's camera app. HMD said it worked closely with Qualcomm, and also collaborated with Google and Facebook to get the implementation right. There's also Dual-Sight, a feature that lets you share content from both the front and rear camera at the same time.\n\nThese videos will also be accompanied with stellar sound, as HMD has partnered with Nokia to use a similar audio setup as the Nokia Ozo virtual reality camera. The Nokia 8 features three microphones that utilize the same algorithm used with the Ozo camera to \"capture audio with immersive 360-degree spatial surround sound.\" When you share a video, the audio still offers hi-fi surround sound even when played on devices without Ozo Audio.\n\nAvailability and price\n\nUnfortunately, the Nokia 8 will never make its way stateside as the company said the U.S. and China required special treatment. It would have to devote a lot more time and money bringing the phone here into a well-established market, where Samsung and Apple reign king.\n\nInstead, the Nokia 8 will launch in Europe and other markets starting in September and it will cost a flagship price of 600 euros (about $704).", "id": "9577948", "details": {"liCnt": 5, "pinCnt": 6}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "With 'pure' Android {"timeCrawl": "21:06:00", "uri": "710544224", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T21:06:00Z", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "source": {"title": "GSMArena.com", "uri": "gsmarena.com", "id": "2022"}, "url": "http://www.gsmarena.com/nokia_has_big_event_today_heres_what_to_expect-news-26788.php", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Nokia (or rather, the new company behind Nokia now - HMD) has an event lined up for today at which it's expected to show off its first real flagship in a while - the Nokia 8. It will take place in London and will start at 7:30PM local time.\n\nBefore we get to the question marks let's take a look at what's more or less certain - the unveiling of the Nokia 8.\n\nThe phone is expected to have a 5.3\" QHD display, a Snapdragon 835 chipset likely paired to 6GB of RAM. Finally, there should be a Zeiss-certified dual camera on the back.\n\nThe Nokia 8 will come in three clors - Silver, Copper Gold and Tempered Blue as leaks suggest.\n\nNokia 2\n\nThe Nokia 2 could share the spotlight with the Nokia 8. We know the phone is getting ready to become official - as evidenced by its leaked renders and a live photo.\n\nHere things become very debatable as Nokia itself insists this device isn't real. A 3G-enabled version of the resurrected Nokia 3310 (2017) has been rumored (and denied) but we wouldn't count it out just yet.\n\nAnd if there is 3G version of the Nokia 3310 (2017) it could very well be announced later today.\n\nUnlikely\n\nIt's highly unlikely that Nokia will announce any other smartphones today. If it were, they would likely be the bigger (to the Nokia 8) Nokia 9 and a middle-of-the-road Nokia 7 with a Snapdragon 660.\n\nGiven the lack of solid recent leaks, we expect the Nokia 9 at a later time. It brings 1080p and 60fps broadcasts to PS4 Pro and more.\n\nWe're overhauling the current master/sub-account system, and introducing the new \"Family on PlayStation Network.\" This new system will offer a more flexible experience for families on PS4 by making it easier to setup PSN accounts for children and customize parental control settings. Below are the new features that will be introduced with family on PSN:\n\nFamily on PSN will allow multiple adults to be part of a single family. The Family Manager can promote another adult inside the family to a Parent/Guardian, who can then customize parental control levels of children's accounts.\n\nBefore this update, the same parental controls were applied to all users on the same console, including adults. But with 5.00, all controls (including game age ratings) can be individually attuned for each child.\n\nIn place of the current 'Favorite Groups' tab, we're adding a new 'Custom Lists' tab within Friends, which allows you to create and edit custom lists of your friends. This makes it easier for you to manage your friends and access specific groups. For example, you can create a custom list of your Destiny teammates and easily send them raid invites.\n\nIf you own a community, you can now bind your community to your broadcast. When a broadcast is linked to a community, the community button appears on the Live from PlayStation spectator screen. Once a spectator clicks on the community button, they'll be able to jump directly to your community page to check out the details.\n\nWe've added a new setting in PlayStation VR: Display Message to Spectators and Spectators' Comments. Once this is enabled, spectator comments sent during a broadcast is displayed not only in cinematic mode, but also in VR mode. This makes it much easier for VR broadcasters to keep up on comments and communicate with their viewers.\n\nGood news Twitch users: with this update, PS4 Pro will support 1080p 60fps streaming on Twitch.\n\nYou've already been able to share your favorite music to Twitter and Facebook via PlayStation Music, but now you'll also be able to share via messages using your PS4. If your friends are on PS4, they can listen to the track right inside the message by booting up Quick Menu, and if they're on their mobile device, they can jump directly to the Spotify app from the PS Messages app to check out the song.\n\nIn addition, if you're part of multiple message groups, you can now easily leave several groups at once. Just open up Options in the message list, select Leave, and choose the message groups you want to leave.\n\nWe've added a new setting that allows you to disable pop-up notifications while you're watching a movie or TV show on your PS4. This setting is off by default, so go to Settings > Notifications to disable notifications and go uninterrupted during your videos.\n\nFurthermore, you now have the option to turn off message previews on your pop-up notifications. If you turn this setting off, the pop-up notification will hide the message senders' online ID and will display a generic user icon and message instead.\n\nLastly, you'll have the option to change the color of your pop-up notifications to either white (default) or black.\n\nIf you want to keep an eye out on what's happening under Notifications, like the progress of your game downloads/installations or new party invites, you can now access this directly from the Quick Menu so you don't have to step away from your game every time you want to check your notifications.\n\nAlso, we've added a 'Leave Party' option in the Quick Menu, so you can easily exit a party and go right back to playing your game.\n\nIn addition, now you'll see the system clock in the upper-right corner of the screen when you pop open the Quick Menu.\n\nPlayStation VR now supports 5.1ch and 7.1ch virtual surround sound on your headphones when watching Blu-rays and DVDs in Cinematic Mode, making for an even more immersive viewing experience.\n\nWe have a new bracket viewer that shows full tournament brackets for Single Elimination and Double Elimination tournaments on PS4. This makes it easier for you to see the current tournament standings.\n\nWith this update, we're adding the following system language options on PS4: Czech, Greek, Hungarian, Indonesian, Romanian, Thai and Vietnamese.\n\nThe PlayStation 4's system software update 5.00's beta will be available for those who signed up. {"timeCrawl": "03:35:00", "uri": "711229419", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:35:00Z", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "source": {"title": "IndiaToday.in", "uri": "indiatoday.intoday.in", "id": "930"}, "url": "http://indiatoday.intoday.in/technology/story/nokia-8-the-good-and-bad-about-this-flagship-android-phone/1/1028415.html", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "The Nokia 8 is one of the most anticipated smartphones of the last few years. Nokia fans and loyalists have been waiting for years for Nokia to release a high-end smartphone running on Android. The Nokia 8 is crafted from a single block of aluminium, runs on a pure version of Android Nougat, has a crisp and sharp display and comes with dual cameras at the rear with ZEISS optics - Nokia surely seems to have left no stone un-turned with their first flagship smartphone in years.\n\nThe Nokia 8 arrives in an extremely mature and competitive marketplace dominated by the likes of the Samsung Galaxy S8, iPhone 7 and Google Pixel. While a lot of leeway was given to the Nokia 3, 5 and 6 due to their price, no such allowances can be given to the Nokia 8 which aims to compete in the ruthless high-end market.\n\nThe Nokia 8 looks like a fairly accomplished product and an excellent first Android flagship smartphone from HMD Global. However, it does have its share of weaknesses. Here are the 5 ways the Nokia 8 succeeds and 5 areas where the smartphone is lacking:\n\nWhere it shines\n\nExquisite looks and craftsmanship\n\nCarrying forward Nokia's heritage of excellent smartphone design, the Nokia 8 is carved out of a single block of series 6000 aluminum and looks very retro chic. With the Nokia 8's design, HMD Global has managed to retain the soul of Nokia smartphones of old while making it look contemporary and modern.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is an excellent first Android flagship smartphone from HMD Global. However, it does have its share of weaknesses\n\nThe level of craftsmanship is impressive. Each smartphone goes through a 40-stage process of machining, anodising and polishing. Nokia claims that the high-gloss finish on certain variants takes over 20 hours to perfect. If the build quality of the Nokia 3 and Nokia 6 is anything to go by, the Nokia 8 is also sure to continue Nokia's tradition of building smartphones like a tank.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is only 7.3 mm thin in average and 4.3mm thin at the edges. It is available in four colour variants - Polished Blue, Polished Copper, Tempered Blue and Steel.\n\nTop of the line specifications\n\nThe internals of the Nokia 8 are on par with any 2017 flagship out there - that is to say they do not disappoint. The smartphone is powered by Qualcomm's latest flagship processor, the Snapdragon 835 paired with 4GB of RAM, the Adreno 540 GPU and a 3,090mAh battery with QuickCharge 3.0 support.\n\nAdditionally, the smartphone comes with 64GB of internal storage which can be expanded via a microSD card (of up to 256GB) and a fingerprint sensor embedded into the home button up front. Many flagship smartphones as of late do not feature any sort of expandable storage so Nokia should be lauded for that.\n\nNokia 8 also comes with an innovative heat management solution - a full-length graphite shielded copper cooling pipe dissipates heat across the full length and breadth of the smartphone. Nokia asserts that this allows the smartphone to stay cool even while being pushed.\n\nPixel perfect display\n\nThe Nokia 8 comes with a 5.3-inch Quad HD display with a resolution of 2560 x 1440. It is covered by 2.5D gorilla Glass 5 for protection against scratches. Aside from the Quad HD resolution, what makes this display stand out is the fact that it has a particularly high maximum brightness of 700 Nits and comes with Nokia's trademark Glance Screen which we used to see in Lumia smartphones of old.\n\nAdditionally, because of the relatively smaller size of the display, the pixel density (544 ppi) is higher than most smartphones out there with QuadHD displays. This should help the Nokia 8 display sharper text and images.\n\nStock Android\n\nOne of the biggest talking points of Nokia's entire Android smartphone line-up is the fact it runs on stock Android. Unlike many other smartphone manufacturers who choose to skin Android to a point that it fails to look like Google's operating system altogether, Nokia has decided to leave Android untouched.\n\nAlso Read: Nokia 8 launched: Specs, top features, expected India price and everything you must know\n\nThese OEM skins are full of bloat, tend to lag with time and worst of all, do not get timely Android version updates. Bucking this trend, the marketing for Nokia's Android line-up reads - 'Pure, secure and up-to date'. The Nokia 8 runs on a 100 percent stock build of Android 7.1.1 Nougat right out of the box with no extraneous third-party apps and overlays.\n\nNokia has also promised that the smartphone will be updated to Android O in the future. While it is just a promise for now and we will have to see how Nokia lives up to it, the company does boldly claim that they will be one of the first, if not the first non Google manufacturers to release Android O to their smartphones.\n\nA generous dose of multimedia features\n\nNokia, through their partnership with lens-maker Carl Zeiss has always been known for making great camera phones - just look at the Nokia N95, Lumia 1020 and Nokia 808 PureView for proof. With the Nokia 8, HMD Global aims to add another chapter to this storied history.\n\nThe Nokia 8 comes with a dual camera setup at the rear with ZEISS optics - a 13MP primary RGB (color) sensor paired with a 13MP monochrome (black and white) sensor which allows for the capture of depth of field information and helps in low-light photography. The rear camera setup can also shoots videos in 4K and comes with phase detection auto-focus and a dual-LED flash.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is carved out of a single block of series 6000 aluminum and looks modern yet pleasantly nostalgic\n\nUnlike many other smartphones where the secondary sensor is reduced to being a gimmick that shoots just bokeh shots, the secondary camera on the Nokia 8 actually improves low-light shots by capturing more data. On the front of the smartphone is a 13MP sensor with phase detection autofocus which is also made in conjunction with ZEISS optics.\n\nThe Nokia 8 also comes with OZO Audio which allows for the capture of 360 degree spatial surround sound via the phone's three microphones and Nokia's own acoustic algorithms. Nokia claims that these clips can also be played back on other phones which do not have OZO audio. Audio enthusiasts will also like the fact that the Nokia 8 comes with a 3.5mm jack, a port which is fast becoming extinct in today's flagship smartphones.\n\nWhere it lacks\n\nLack of proper waterproofing\n\nWhile most flagships these days such as the Samsung Galaxy S8 and LG G6 come with IP68 dust and water resistance, the Nokia 8 is only IP54 certified. Thus while the Nokia 8 is only splash proof, IP68 smartphones can be dunked in up to 1.5 metre of water for up to 30 minutes making them much more water resistant.\n\nEven the iPhone 7 comes with IP67 water resistance, which while not as good as IP68, still allows you to immerse the phone in water. The Nokia 8 on the other hand is only protected against light splashes of water. Nokia claims that in order to achieve a higher IP rating, they would have had to make trade-offs with the design that they were not willing to take.\n\nWireless charging\n\nThe lack of wireless charging in the Nokia 8 is a bit disappointing. Many smartphones like the Samsung Galaxy S8 and LG G6 feature the 'Qi' wireless charging standard which allows the smartphone to be charged wirelessly when placed on a wireless charging pad.\n\nWhile wireless charging has not taken off that much as of now, many people are big fans of the feature. Also, wireless charging might become mainstream in the coming months with Apple set to include the feature in the upcoming iPhone 7s, iPhone 7s Plus and iPhone 8.\n\nBezels in 2017\n\nWhile the Nokia 8 looks very sleek and classy, it does not come with a bezel-less design seen in recent flagships such as the Samsung Galaxy S8 or the LG G6. The bezels on top and bottom are quite substantial in a day and age where smartphone design is moving towards edge-to-edge displays and minimal screen to body ratios. Even the upcoming iPhone 8 is expected to come with a striking bezel-less design.\n\nStereo speakers\n\nConsidering that the Nokia 8 comes with a 3.5mm headphone jack and audio centric features like OZO Audio, it is disappointing that the smartphone does not come with stereo speakers.\n\nImaging, audio and video has always been the strong points of Nokia and the company could have really capitalised on the same in a way that HTC has done with the U11. Stereo speakers, good earphones out of the box and audio features like Dolby ATMOS would have gone a long way in helping the Nokia 8 stand out from the crowd.\n\nSay no to Hybrid SIM slots\n\nNo one likes a Hybrid SIM slot. What is the point of making a person choose between expanding storage or using his secondary SIM card? Considering how much HMD Global stresses on the importance of a stress free user experience, the use of a Hybrid SIM Slot on the Nokia 8, which basically holds a user to ransom, is very puzzling.\n\nAlso Read: Nokia 8 launched: Ozo Audio, Zeiss camera, good design are 3 of its top 8 features", "id": "9816333", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Nokia 8: The good and bad about this flagship Android phone", "image": "http://media2.intoday.in/indiatoday/images/stories/nokia-8_559_081817083402.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "concepts": [{"label": {"eng": "Smartphone"}, "id": "302682", "score": 5, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smartphone"}, {"label": {"eng": "Google"}, "id": "302865", "score": 5, "type": "org",
