{"timeCrawl": "03:00:00", "uri": "710651413", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:00:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"title": "The Asian Age", "uri": "asianage.com", "id": "2273"}, "url": "http://www.asianage.com/technology/mobiles-tabs/170817/new-nokia-8-phone-targets-surging-demand-for-video-streaming.html", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "The Android device, due out in September, will potentially beat rivals on price but will still face fierce competition.\n\nHMD Global, the Finnish start-up looking to reinvigorate the Nokia phone brand, unveiled the Nokia 8 on August 16, hoping to cash in on rising consumer demand for high-quality audio and video features.\n\nThe Android device, due out in September, will potentially beat rivals on price but will still face fierce competition, with Apple's highly anticipated 10th anniversary iPhone also expected next month and Samsung's Galaxy Note 8 set to hit the market next week.\n\nWith a suggested price tag of around $703 (approximately Rs 45,000), the Nokia 8 undercuts Apple, which typically offers a stripped down version of its latest phones for a similar price but charges hundreds of euros more for memory and key features.\n\nThe new top-of-the-line Nokia sports a dual-sight video feature which enables simultaneous live-streaming on social media networks from both front and rear cameras on a split screen. It has licensed lens technology from camera maker Zeiss.\n\nIt is the most high-end phone so far from HMD, which was set up late last year and made a splash in May when it revived Nokia's classic 3310 feature handset in new brightly coloured versions.\n\nOther features of the Nokia 8, which will also compete with Huawei's recently launched P10, include surround-sound audio technology made for Nokia's own virtual reality camera OZO for Hollywood professionals.\n\n\"This is especially meant for millennial creators, people who want to share what's happening every day,\" HMD's chief marketing officer Pekka Rantala said.\n\nHMD products are built by a unit of Foxconn, which acquired the manufacturing and distribution assets of the former Nokia phone business from Microsoft last year.\n\nOnce the world's dominant phonemaker, Nokia Oyj sold its handset operations to Microsoft in 2014, leaving it to focus on telecoms network equipment.\n\nHMD is owned by Smart Connect LP, a private equity fund managed by Jean-Francois Baril, a long-serving former senior vice president of Nokia. It took over the Nokia feature phones business in December and has a licensing deal giving it sole use of the Nokia brand on all phones and tablets.\n\nIt has so far launched four smartphones and five feature phones, including the 3310.\n\nRantala said he was happy with initial sales of the previous smartphones, but declined to disclose any sales figures yet.\n\nHMD will pay Nokia royalties for the brand and patents.\n\nLast month, HMD announced that its CEO Arto Nummela, a former Nokia executive, was leaving the company for personal reasons, without elaborating.", "id": "9601378", "details": {"timeCrawl": "02:11:00", "uri": "711208813", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:24:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"title": "Comicbook.com", "uri": "comicbook.com", "id": "2107"}, "url": "http://comicbook.com/gaming/2017/08/17/playstation-4-system-update-5-out-today-features-revealed/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369188", "body": "Start Slideshow Back to Article Slide of Start Slideshow\n\nToday, a few of you lucky PS4 beta testers are going to get the chance to download and update to PlayStation 4 system version 5.0. A while back Sony opened sign-ups to participate in the testing of this firmware, and if you were selected, you should be receiving an email some time today.\n\nWhether you were selected or not doesn't matter. 5.0 is coming to everyone very shortly, and today Sony officially revealed all of the system features. Not shockingly, these line up almost exactly with our version 5.0 leak from a while ago. This is great news for some of you, and nasty news for most of you.\n\nWe're going to outline the new system 5.0 features in order of most importance. Sony thinks that the new family management system is the headlining feature. We think that's dumb. We're going to kick off with all of the new social bells and whistles, including broadcasting enhancements for your Twitch streams and community changes. Then we'll outline some exciting new features for PS VR owners and some quality of life improvements that we think everyone will enjoy. These are all pulled from the official announcement, so no more guess-work.\n\nLet's begin.\n\nPreviousSlide 1/6Next Broadcast Feature Updates Communities\n\nIf you own a community, you can now bind your community to your broadcast. When a broadcast is linked to a community, the community button appears on the Live from PlayStation spectator screen. Once a spectator clicks on the community button, they'll be able to jump directly to your community page to check out the details.\n\nPlayStation VR\n\nWe've added a new setting in PlayStation VR: Display Message to Spectators and Spectators' Comments. Once this is enabled, spectator comments sent during a broadcast is displayed not only in cinematic mode, but also in VR mode. This makes it much easier for VR broadcasters to keep up on comments and communicate with their viewers.\n\nPlayStation 4 Pro\n\nGood news Twitch users: with this update, PS4 Pro will support 1080p 60fps streaming on Twitch.\n\nPreviousSlide 2/6Next VR, Competitive Gaming, and Social\n\nVirtual Surround Sound on PS VR\n\nPlayStation VR now supports 5.1ch and 7.1ch virtual surround sound on your headphones when watching Blu-rays and DVDs in Cinematic Mode, making for an even more immersive viewing experience\n\nImproved Tournaments Bracket Viewer\n\nWe have a new bracket viewer that shows full tournament brackets for Single Elimination and Double Elimination tournaments on PS4. This makes it easier for you to see the current tournament standings.\n\nNew System Language Additions\n\nWith this update, we're adding the following system language options on PS4: Czech, Greek, Hungarian, Indonesian, Romanian, Thai and Vietnamese.\n\nFriend List Management\n\nIn place of the current 'Favorite Groups' tab, we're adding a new 'Custom Lists' tab within Friends, which allows you to create and edit custom lists of your friends. This makes it easier for you to manage your friends and access specific groups. For example, you can create a custom list of your Destiny teammates and easily send them raid invites.\n\nPreviousSlide 3/6Next Messaging and Notifications Messages Improvements\n\nYou've already been able to share your favorite music to Twitter and Facebook via PlayStation Music, but now you'll also be able to share via messages using your PS4. If your friends are on PS4, they can listen to the track right inside the message by booting up Quick Menu, and if they're on their mobile device, they can jump directly to the Spotify app from the PS Messages app to check out the song.\n\nIn addition, if you're part of multiple message groups, you can now easily leave several groups at once. Just open up Options in the message list, select Leave, and choose the message groups you want to leave.\n\nNotifications Updates\n\nWe've added a new setting that allows you to disable pop-up notifications while you're watching a movie or TV show on your PS4. This setting is off by default, so go to Settings > Notifications to disable notifications and go uninterrupted during your videos.\n\nFurthermore, you now have the option to turn off message previews on your pop-up notifications. If you turn this setting off, the pop-up notification will hide the message senders' online ID and will display a generic user icon and message instead.\n\nLastly, you'll have the option to change the color of your pop-up notifications to either white (default) or black.\n\nPreviousSlide 4/6Next Quick Menu Updates Quick Menu Updates\n\nIf you want to keep an eye out on what's happening under Notifications, like the progress of your game downloads/installations or new party invites, you can now access this directly from the Quick Menu so you don't have to step away from your game every time you want to check your notifications.\n\nAlso, we've added a 'Leave Party' option in the Quick Menu, so you can easily exit a party and go right back to playing your game. In addition, now you'll see the system clock in the upper-right corner of the screen when you pop open the Quick Menu.\n\nPreviousSlide 5/6Next Family / Account Management Overhaul Family on PSN\n\nWe're overhauling the current master/sub-account system, and introducing the new \"Family on PlayStation Network.\" This new system will offer a more flexible experience for families on PS4 by making it easier to setup PSN accounts for children and customize parental control settings. Below are the new features that will be introduced with family on PSN:\n\nFamily Manager, Parent/Guardian\n\nFamily on PSN will allow multiple adults to be part of a single family. The Family Manager can promote another adult inside the family to a Parent/Guardian, who can then customize parental control levels of children's accounts.\n\nIndividualized Parental Controls\n\nBefore this update, the same parental controls were applied to all users on the same console, including adults. But with 5.00, all controls (including game age ratings) can be individually attuned for each child.\n\nPreviousSlide 6/6Are you excited about version 5.0? {"timeCrawl": "18:47:00", "uri": "710489549", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:47:00Z", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "source": {"title": "Pocket-lint", "uri": "pocket-lint.com", "id": "3699"}, "url": "http://www.pocket-lint.com/news/141926-nokia-8-official-flagship-power-meets-dual-camera-skills", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "HMD Global, the guardian of the Nokia smartphone brand, has announced the Nokia 8, revealing the flagship smartphone that fans have been waiting all year for.\n\nThe Nokia 8 will take the fight to the likes of the OnePlus 5, HTC U11 and Samsung Galaxy S8, sitting on the powerful Snapdragon 835 platform and offering a 5.3-inch 2560 x 1440 pixel display.\n\nSo what makes this phone different apart from the Nokia name on the back? Well that comes down to the camera.\n\nNokia has revived its partnership with Zeiss, with the precision optics company teaming up with HMD Global to work on the dual camera on the rear of the phone. This isn't a dual camera like the iPhone 7 Plus or LG G6, so there's no wide or telephoto lens, instead this is about quality first and foremost.\n\nIt offers the same approach as the Huawei P10, with two sensors, one capturing RGB colour data and the second concentrating on monochrome. Combining the data from the two sensors should result in better image quality - no matter what the shooting conditions are.\n\nBut that's not all: there's also a 13-megapixel front camera (so that's three 13-megapixel cameras on this phone), with the unique offering being the ability to not only take photos from both cameras at the same time (front and rear), but to be able to livestream video from both. That means you can have Facebook Live watching what you're filming and your reaction at the same time. Nokia calls this Dual-Sight.\n\nBeyond the camera, Nokia is offering Ozo Audio, with binaural audio capture, but aiming to preserve that, so when you capture a 360 audio and share a video, others get the benefit of that great audio too.\n\nComing in four colours - with Polished Copper very much being the most interesting and unique - the Nokia 8 runs pure Android 7 with the promise of a quick update to Android O when it becomes available.\n\nWhile the Nokia 8 isn't quite hitting the asking price of the likes of the HTC U11. Priced at \u20ac599 (UK prices still to be confirmed), the challenge is really competing with devices like the OnePlus 5, which is \u00a3449, a healthy bit cheaper.\n\nThe Nokia 8 will be available globally in September; UK prices and networks have not yet been confirmed.", "id": "9544650", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Nokia 8 official: Flagship power meets dual camera skills - {"timeCrawl": "11:59:00", "uri": "711423897", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T11:59:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"title": "Which? magazine", "uri": "which.co.uk", "id": "2381"}, "url": "http://www.which.co.uk/news/2017/08/nokia-8-announced-a-mobile-phone-designed-for-live-streaming/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "At \u00a3550, the Nokia 8 is attempting to compete with high-end smartphones like the Samsung Galaxy S8. But does it have the mettle?\n\nFinnish brand Nokia is continuing its attempt to clamber up the ranks in the smartphone market with the Nokia 8, a flagship smartphone with a few interesting features.\n\nPerhaps most interesting is the Nokia 8's 'Dual-Sight'. You can snap photos and record videos using both front and rear cameras at the same time - and you can see how these look on the phone's display via its split-screen feature.\n\nYou can record 4K video on the Nokia 8, too. Plus the phone records 360\u00b0 audio, which means it should capture sound from all directions for more immersive playback.\n\nYou should be able to buy the Nokia 8 at some point in September, and it will cost around \u00a3550 to buy outright. This price tag places it among the more expensive smartphones we've seen, but is it worth considering over well-known models such as the Samsung Galaxy S8 and LG G6?\n\nIt's made from aluminium for an expensive look, has a generous 64GB on-board storage and dual cameras on its rear. We can't wait until we get full results from our test lab, to bring you our definitive verdict.\n\nIn the meantime, we cover some of the phone's key specs, and whether it's shaping up to be one of the best smartphones of 2017, below.\n\nMobile phone reviews - get the best smartphone for your budget\n\nMore and more mobile phone manufacturers are sticking two camera lenses on the back of handsets, to try to improve photo and video quality.\n\nNokia has jumped on the bandwagon with the 8, with 13Mp colour and monochrome lenses. The theory behind this is that you'll get better detail even in low-light shots, and you'll be able to focus more quickly on your subject. It also has a 13Mp front-facing camera for selfie fans.\n\nWe test all phones for camera quality in a range of light conditions. We can't wait to see whether the Nokia 8 delivers on its grand claims.\n\nUnder the hood, the Nokia 8 has the Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 processor. This is the latest Snapdragon chip in the series, and means that the new Nokia should speed through everyday tasks.\n\nIt should also be able to handle the latest, graphic-intensive games, and flitting between several different apps. This means the Nokia 8 could be a good choice both for people who use their phones mainly for texts and light web browsing, as well as people who use their phones for several hours a day.\n\nThe Nokia 8 runs on Google's Android operating system. Many manufacturers do the same, but modify how it looks for a more bespoke experience.\n\nHowever, Nokia is offering Android in its pure form with its new smartphone. Nokia says that this means there will be no unnecessary apps that you can't delete - instead, you have more storage space to fill with exactly what you want.\n\nThe Finnish brand also promises monthly security updates to the Nokia 8, which may give you peace of mind.\n\nAs you'd expect from a phone this expensive, it has a fingerprint scanner for so you can quickly unlock your device.\n\nMany expensive smartphones are designed with decent water-resistance. For example, you can submerge the Samsung Galaxy S8 for half an hour in 1.5 metres of water, and it should still work normally. It's somewhat disappointing that the Nokia 8 can only withstand 'splashes' of water, and that an accidental drop in the toilet could render it completely useless.", "id": "9886868", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Nokia 8 announced: a mobile phone designed for live streaming - Which? {"timeCrawl": "19:22:00", "uri": "710503196", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T19:22:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"title": "Reuters India", "uri": "in.reuters.com", "id": "630"}, "url": "https://in.reuters.com/article/nokia-phones-idINKCN1AW2ET", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "HELSINKI (Reuters) - HMD Global, the Finnish start-up looking to reinvigorate the Nokia phone brand, unveiled the Nokia 8 on Wednesday, hoping to cash in on rising consumer demand for high-quality audio and video features.\n\nThe Android device, due out in September, will potentially beat rivals on price but will still face fierce competition, with Apple's highly anticipated 10th anniversary iPhone also expected next month and Samsung's (005930.KS) Galaxy Note 8 set to hit the market next week.\n\nWith a suggested price tag of around 599 euros ($703), the Nokia 8 undercuts Apple, which typically offers a stripped down version of its latest phones for a similar price but charges hundreds of euros more for memory and key features.\n\nThe new top-of-the-line Nokia sports a dual-sight video feature which enables simultaneous live-streaming on social media networks from both front and rear cameras on a split screen. It has licensed lens technology from camera maker Zeiss.\n\nIt is the most high-end phone so far from HMD, which was set up late last year and made a splash in May when it revived Nokia's classic 3310 feature handset in new brightly coloured versions.\n\nOther features of the Nokia 8, which will also compete with Huawei's recently launched [HWT.UL] P10, include surround-sound audio technology made for Nokia's own virtual reality camera OZO for Hollywood professionals.\n\n\"This is especially meant for millennial creators, people who want to share what's happening every day,\" HMD's chief marketing officer Pekka Rantala said.\n\nHMD is owned by Smart Connect LP, a private equity fund managed by Jean-Francois Baril, a long-serving former senior vice president of Nokia. It took over the Nokia feature phones business in December and has a licensing deal giving it sole use of the Nokia brand on all phones and tablets.\n\nIt has so far launched four smartphones and five feature phones, including the 3310. [nL5N1GB0JW}\n\nRantala said he was happy with initial sales of the previous smartphones, but declined to disclose any sales figures yet.\n\nHMD will pay Nokia royalties for the brand and {"timeCrawl": "02:08:00", "uri": "710636428", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T17:37:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"title": "PCMag India", "uri": "in.pcmag.com", "id": "19060"}, "url": "http://in.pcmag.com/nokia/116249/preview/nokia-8-preview", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Here is a first look at the newly launched Nokia 8 flagship smartphone that will start hitting markets this month\n\nHere's the thing, if you thought Nokia will be back in the smartphone arms race just like in heartbeat then you were foolishly mistaken because that wasn't about to happen overnight. These days the tech development curve moves at a frenetic pace and HMD Global might be fully of prodigious talent and a lot of Nokia IP it wasn't going to be an innovation machine at first brush. At that's what happened at MWC - they played the nostalgia card brilliantly with 3310, they had the great software and rock solid phones in the Nokia 6, Nokia 5 and Nokia 3; but neither of these were earth shattering. But now, HMD Global is turning up some levers as it has launched the new Nokia 8.\n\nThe new Nokia 8 is many things, but what it is not a flashy headline grabbing Android smartphone. It is purely Nokia in soul and it is a functional beast. Some elements which debuted on the phones like the Nokia 6 are ever present in arguably a grander way and then there are some unique things which hint at a better tomorrow.\n\nLet's start with the design. The Nokia 8 is a refinement of the design language HMD Global showcased with the Nokia 6 and Nokia 5. It has rounded corners, a slim profile of 7.3mm all in a solid series 6000 aluminium chassis. It is IP 54 certified and largely looks great especially in the polished blue and copper finishes.\n\nIt is also compact as it has a 5.3-inch screen not something which is outlandish in terms of size.\n\nThe screen itself is impressive though a tad washed out. It has a quad HD resolution and despite being an LCD panel it has natural colours and decent viewing angles apart from being very bright at 700 nits.\n\nInternally, this phone has some of the best specs one would find on an Android phone in 2017. It has the Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 chipset, 4GB RAM and 64GB of internal storage which can be further bolstered with the microSD card slot.\n\nTo manage great performance, this phone also has a copper heat pipe embedded which should help alleviate stressful workloads and not make the phone burn like a furnace. The phone in the short while we tested performed well with it being on par with the Google Pixel and the OnePlus 5 in that department.\n\nOf course, HMD Global's commitment to providing a stock Android Nougat experience helps matters here, but its executives also say that they are working overtime on the Android O update and the Nokia 8 will be surely one of the first phones in the market to deliver that software experience.\n\nThe real innovation on the phone comes in form of its cameras. It has dual 13-megapixel sensors on the back augmented with Carl Zeiss optics and an optically stabilised RGB lens that also has a laser focusing system. HMD Global says this will ensure great image quality as it uses 1.12 micron sub pixels combined with some magic of computational photography and the fusing of an RGB image with a black and white image from the monochrome lens.\n\nIn PCMag India's short term with the phone, the experience was quite impressive. HMD Global has gone to great lengths to make sure the camera provides a differentiated experience. One of the interesting things it has done is a new feature called dual sight shot. Basically, this activates all three cameras - the two on the back and the one on the front which by the way is the same one as the RGB sensor on the back showcasing both perspectives of view in a split screen format.\n\n\u200b\n\nThe Nokia 8 goes one step further by integrating live streaming on Facebook and YouTube on the stock camera app allowing people to not only live stream but also use this unique dual view mode on these platforms.\n\n\u200b\n\nVideo on this phone should be great as firstly all three cameras shoot in 4K and now this becomes the first phone in the world to incorporate Nokia's critically acclaimed OZO audio technology. For OZO integration, HMD Global is using high dynamic range microphones and also the OZO algorithm which could make it the best phone in the market to record loud video on. Imagine a techno party, a live concert, this should be the phone HMD Global says should be with you and going by Nokia's lineage we aren't doubting its capabilities.\n\nOther frills include a front mounted fingerprint scanner, a rather decent 3,090mAh battery with fast charging and a promise that it could come to India by October for around Rs 45,000, this could be actually the flagship Android everyone should be buying instead of the ostentatious and gimmicky Samsung Galaxy S8. But hey, wait for our review no, that will actually be the true test of the pudding that HMD Global is cooking up.\n\nDisclaimer: HMD Global paid for the writer's travel and stay in London to cover Now it's easier than ever to setup PSN accounts for kids, while also managing customization of parental control settings. PS4 understanding there are multiple adults in a household that should be able to manage the family features. Having a broadcast linked to a community will have a button appear on the Live from PlayStation spectator screen. All a spectator needs to do is click the community button and they can jump right to the community page to check out any details.\n\nPlayStation VR has also been fine-tuned with new setting PlayStation VR: Display Message to Spectators and Spectator's Comments. Enabling either will show spectator comments sent during broadcast to display in cinematic mode and VR mode. Making it easier for a broadcaster to keep up with comments to communicate in a timely manner. It's like being able to delete multiple games at once.\n\nThe new feature to disable pop-up notifications while watching movie's or Tv shows on the PS4 has become available. The setting is on by default, but if now going to Settings>Notifications the disable notifications will mean uninterrupted video bliss. PlayStation users will also have the option to turn off message previews on pop-up notifications. Turing the setting off the pop-up notification will hide the message senders' online ID, displaying a generic icon and message instead. The final feature for messaging is the changing of color of pop-up notifications with either white (default) or black.\n\nThe Quick Menu has seen some tweaks too making it even easier to access features without having to pause whatever one might be doing. Now players can check Notifications such as the progress of game downloads/installations or new party invites that be accessed with ease from the Quick Menu meaning less down time. The ability to 'Leave Party' from the Quick Menu has been added too, which again is less down time. The system clock is also promptly displayed in the upper-right corner of the screen when accessing the Quick Menu.\n\nAn improved tournament bracket viewer has seen some adjustment, showing full tournament brackets for Single Elimination and Double Elimination tournaments on PS4. Making it easier to see current tournament standing.\n\nThe final piece for this update is new system language additions, update 5.0 giving PS4: Czech, Greek, Hungarian, Indonesian, Romanian, Thai and Vietnamese.\n\nIt's a hefty update that brings some great features to the PS4 and PS4 Pro only improving upon the changes and features already added and built in. {"timeCrawl": "10:39:00", "uri": "710825585", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T02:25:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"title": "bgr.in", "uri": "bgr.in", "id": "5775"}, "url": "http://www.bgr.in/news/nokia-8-hands-on-and-first-impressions-roundup-heres-what-previews-say-of-the-device/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "The much-rumored Nokia 8 was made official last night in London. HMD Global's smartphone comes with premium design, top-of-the-line specifications, and it will be competing against other flagship devices in the high-end segment. The Nokia 8 is priced at \u20ac599 (approximately Rs 45,000), and is set to go on sale globally early September. Some of the publications got hands-on time with the new Nokia 8, and here's a look at their first impressions.\n\nSince the launch of the first Nokia-branded Android smartphones, HMD Global hasn't stopped highlighting the design. With the Nokia 8 it is no different either. As Pocket-lint puts it, \"The Nokia 8 starts life as a block of aluminium, hewn into smartphone form, with a soft curve across the back and rounded edges to make it sit comfortably in the hand.\"\n\nThe Nokia 8 will be available in four colors - Polished Blue, Polished Copper, Tempered Blue, and Steel. Two of the colors come with a glossy finish, while the other two come with a less glamorous matt finish, albeit with more grip. \"It's particularly smart of Nokia to let customers choose between matt and polished finishes - we like that a lot - because while the polished finish looks more striking, the matt finishes offer more grip. It's a tough choice, but good to let consumers make that decision,\" T3 says.\n\nUnder the hood is Qualcomm's latest Snapdragon 835 SoC paired with 4GB of RAM. On paper at least the smartphone seems more than capable of handling any and every task thrown at it, and early impressions across publications are in line with that. What also aids in good performance is the fact that the Nokia 8 runs on stock Android 7.1.1 out-of-the-box. The company has promised Android O update as soon as Google rolls it out. ALSO READ: Nokia 8 vs Samsung Galaxy S8 vs HTC U11 vs Sony Xperia XZ Premium: Price, specifications, and features compared\n\nWhat's caught everyone's eye is however the cooling system underneath. HMD Global says that Nokia 8 comes with graphite shielded copper cooling pipes that dissipate heat across the length and breadth of the handset. As GSMArena notes, \"...we want to commend HMD on how cool the Nokia 8 runs. The heat pipe and graphite shield must be doing some work as we re-ran multiple benchmarks in quick succession and the phone didn't even feel warm. Seriously, we can't tell where the chipset is by feel (usually, it's obvious on phones with poor heat management).\"\n\nAmong the highlights of the Nokia 8 is the dual-camera setup at the back, and the smartphone is being touted as one that is aimed at content creators. The setup includes a pair of 13-megapixel snappers - one shoots in RGB, and one in monochrome. The camera has been developed in partnership with Carl ZEISS. But the company is focusing on a feature it calls 'Bothie'. In essence, the Nokia 8 camera lets users shoot photos or videos using both the front and back cameras simultaneously. There is also a feature to livestream on social media directly from the camera app.\n\nThe dual-camera setup, and the Bothie feature is clearly designed with the over-sharing millennials in mind. \"The focus on livestreaming underscores where the new Nokia is headed as it targets a younger crowd more likely to use the feature on Snapchat or Instagram,\" Cnet says. \"It marks the latest comeback attempt from the brand, which was once the largest phone maker in the world by far but was ultimately crushed by newer players like Apple, Google and Samsung.\" ALSO READ: Nokia 8 vs OnePlus 5 vs Honor 8 Pro: Price, specifications and features compared\n\nSo far, early impressions about the Nokia 8 have been quite positive. But we will get a closer look at how good the smartphone is, once the first reviews are out. {"timeCrawl": "10:39:00", "uri": "710825587", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T06:25:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"title": "bgr.in", "uri": "bgr.in", "id": "5775"}, "url": "http://www.bgr.in/news/nokia-8-from-dual-sight-bothie-mode-to-liquid-cooling-here-are-the-top-5-features/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "HMD Global has launched its latest smartphone - Nokia 8 - with a refreshed design and the latest Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 which promises a lag-free experience while using the smartphone. The smartphone sports a full-metal unibody, which looks premium, thanks to its metal edges.\n\nThe smartphone is expected to be priced at \u20ac599 (approximately Rs 45,000). The device will be available globally starting early September. Before it goes on sale, here are the key features of the Nokia's recently launched flagship. Here are five noteworthy features of the Nokia 8:\n\nDual-camera setup with OIS\n\nOne of the USPs of Nokia 8 is its camera. The Nokia 8 features a 13-megapixel dual-camera setup at the rear with one sensor meant for RGB, while other captures monochrome information. The primary sensor comes with Optical Image Stabilization (OIS) and PDAF support, f/2.0 aperture, and IR range finder. The dual-cameras are powered by ZEISS optics.\n\nOn the front, the device houses a 13-megapixel front-facing camera for selfies and video calling. The front camera is equipped with PDAF, 1.12um and f/2.0. ALSO READ: Nokia 8: Here's how the 'bothie' dual-camera setup works\n\nWith the Nokia 8, you can simultaneously shoot with the front and rear cameras. The company calls it the Bothie mode, which enables a split-screen with photo and video from the two cameras. It claims the Nokia 8 is a world-first phone to enable Dual-Sight video that can be live-streamed natively and in real-time to Facebook and YouTube.\n\nBrighter display\n\nThe Nokia 8 features a screen size of 5.3-inch IPS 2K resolution display and 554 ppi. Nokia says that the phone can reach a brightness of 700 nits which would allow you to read clearly under bright sunlight. In comparison, the new iPad Pro does 600 nits. The display is protected by Corning Gorilla Glass 5 on top of 2.5D glass.\n\nOZO Audio for better spatial experience\n\nThe Nokia 8 comes with OZO Audio offering a 360-degree spatial audio experience for video recordings. The feature allows users to record 4K videos with 360-degree spatial audio with Audio Focus. The company says it helps in reducing noise and ambient sound in videos. ALSO READ: Nokia 8 hands-on and first impressions roundup: Here's what previews say of the device\n\nLiquid cooling on a smartphone\n\nMoving on, HMD Global has introduced Liquid Cooling facility with the Nokia 8 smartphone. Now, considering Nokia 8 is running the Qualcomm's latest Snapdragon 835 chipset paired with 4GB of RAM in the phone, the device is expected to heat up. However, to prevent that, the design, innovation engineers have come up with a solution to avoid over heating of the device. The company has inserted a graphite shielded copper cooling pipe that scatters the heat generated by the chipset and equally divides it throughout the device, hence keeping the device from bursting into flames. ALSO READ: Android O rollout to begin on August 21, Google Pixel first in line: Report\n\nPure Android because latest updates matter\n\nThe Nokia 8 runs pure stock Android 7.1.1 Android Nougat OS. However, HMD Global has promised to offer the latest Android O updates to its users without any delay. If reports are anything to go by, Nokia 8 will be among the first smartphones to get the Android O update as soon as it rolls out officially. After months of anticipation for its first flagship smartphone, HMD Global has unveiled the Nokia 8 as promised. We first had an idea about this when early sketches popped up online. Some images were also leaked showing an iris scanner and a bezel-less display. We were almost certain about its final form when we saw some believable images, followed by that copper-colored Nokia 8 and the different variants listed on GFXBench and AnTuTu.\n\nOld and new fans alike of Nokia will want this new Nokia 8 because it's the most premium offering yet since the brand was given a new lease on life by HMD. The phone records with both cameras at the same time to show two images or videos in a single media file. The idea is nothing new because we've heard something similar before but Nokia is banking on this feature to sell the phone. Apparently, there are people who think there is a more practical way to show off your surroundings or the moment.\n\nThe feature is officially called as \"Bothies\". It sounds a bit awkward but at least we know it's Nokia that wants to make it a household name. The company has this tagline: Be less Selfie. Be more #Bothie. It's up to you how you will take advantage of this feature. The phone runs Android 7.1.1 Nougat OS out of the box but it can be upgraded to Android O once the latter is available.\n\nHMD Global will roll out the Nokia 8 next month. Europe will get it first on September 6 with a 599 Euro ($705) starting price. Feel free to choose among these color options: Polished Copper, Steel, Tempered Blue, and Polished Blue. Beta users will receive an email with instruction on how to get started.\n\nMore in News: Tired of Changing Consoles for PC, Xbox, and PlayStation? Here is a Solution 8 Updates to Sony PS4 Family on PS Network\n\nThe current master/sub-account system is receiving a major overhaul and being rechristened the 'Family on PlayStation Network'. This will make it easier to setup PSN accounts for children and customise parental control settings.\n\nFriend List Management\n\nSony has replaced the 'Custom Lists' with 'Favourite Groups' tab within 'Friends', which allows users to create and edit custom lists of their friends -- making it easier to manage friends and access specific groups.\n\nBroadcast Feature Updates\n\nThe latest update brings broadcast updates for Communities, PlayStation VR and PlayStation 4 Pro.\n\nCommunities get their own broadcast live button which appears on PlayStation spectator screen. Clicking on the community button will redirect the user to the community page.\n\nPlayStation Pro will now support 1090p 60fps streaming on Twitch.\n\nMessage Improvements\n\nNow users can share tracks from PlayStation Music via messages on PS4. PS4 users can listen directly to the shared track via the Quick Menu and those on mobile will be redirected to the Spotify app to check out the song.\n\nThe new update has also made it easy to leave groups. Just open up the 'Options' in the message list and select 'Leave' and then choose the ones you want to leave.\n\nNotifications Updates\n\nA new setting has been added to notifications which allows users to switch off pop-up notifications while watching a movie or TV show on the PS4. This setting is turned off by default. Go to 'Settings', then 'Notifications' and click on 'Disable Pop-ups While Playing Video'.\n\nMessage previews on pop-up notifications can also be turned off via notification settings. Turning off message previews will hide the message senders' online ID and display a generic user icon instead.\n\nUsers can also change the colour of the pop-up notification to either white or black.\n\nQuick Menu Updates\n\nUsers will now be able to keep an eye on what's happening like the progress of your game download/installation or new party invites can be directly accessed from under Notifications in the in-game Quick Menu.\n\n'Leave Party' option has also been added to the Quick Menu which allows users to exit a party and go back to playing the game.\n\nUsers will also be greeted with a new system clock whenever they open the quick menu.\n\nVirtual Surround Sound on PS VR\n\nPlayStation VR now has added support for 5.1 and 7.1 channel virtual surround sound on headphones while watching Blu-rays and DVDs in Cinematic Mode.\n\nImproved Tournaments Bracket Viewer\n\nThe tournament standings bracket viewer has been updated and now shows full tournament brackets for Single {"timeCrawl": "16:16:00", "uri": "710988299", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:45:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"title": "itwire.com", "uri": "itwire.com", "id": "6586"}, "url": "https://www.itwire.com/home-it/79518-nokia-8-flagship-arrives-before-galaxy-note-8-and-presumed-iphone-8.html", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Rushing to market to beat rival flagships to market, the Nokia 8 is the first Nokia flagship with ZEISS optics, OZO spatial 360-degree sound, 'pure' Android and plenty more including an $899 price.\n\nComing pumped with 64GB storage (expandable with up to 256GB more via MicroSD), 4GB RAM, Cat 9 4G LTE, twin ZEISS optics lenses on the back, Android 7.1.1 and plenty more, Nokia has finally released the Android flagship of a type its fans would have wanted all those years ago, had Microsoft not meddled in Nokia's destiny and burned its platform with Windows Mobile madness.\n\nThat madness destroyed Nokia smartphones, its reputation, its business and its Linux-based operating systems, but after Microsoft's embarrassing broken Windows Mobile debacle, HMD Global licensed the Nokia brand name for consumer Nokia devices, and the once market leader has returned to the market.\n\nHMD Global started off carefully in bringing new Nokias to market, starting off with lower-end 3, 5 and 6 numbered models at prices of $249, $329 and $399 respectively, as an iTWire writer covered at the time.\n\nThe company then announced in early July that it was bringing ZEISS optics back to future Nokia branded smartphones, presumably of the flagship variety, as reported in iTWire at the time.\n\nThe we fast forward to late July, nearly exactly a month ago, with HMD Global's CEO, Arto Nummela, parting ways with the company in mysterious circumstances, but in no way stopping the Nokia train that has once against started hurtling down the tracks towards a very different smartphone landscape in 2017.\n\nSo, this now leads us to Nokia's newest flagship smartphone, the Nokia 8, with three promised \"firsts in one precision designed flagship,\" with these headline features being as follows;\n\nArriving for pre-order from today, Friday August 18, Nokia promises performance, pure Android and \"the most advanced aluminium unibody design to date,\" and says its Nokia 8 \"has been designed from the ground up with the consumer in mind to deliver unique content capture and sharing experiences.\"\n\nTo that end, Nokia is introducing the concept not of a Selfie but a \"Bothie\", with a claimed \"world-first in enabling Dual-Sight video to be livestreamed natively and in real-time to social feeds such as Facebook and YouTube.\"\n\nWe are told that \"Dual-Sight simultaneously harnesses both the front and rear cameras in a split screen visual for both photos and videos. With just one touch, this world-first livestream capability gives more immersive experiences for those who love to create and share special memories.\"\n\nThis design is claimed \"to help you create and share the full picture\", with the \"front and rear-facing cameras on the Nokia 8 have been co-developed with ZEISS optics for an optimum all round experience.\"\n\nThe promise is that \"content creators can natively broadcast their unique #Bothie stories to social media through the Dual-Sight functionality located within the camera app. Fans can also enjoy unlimited photo and video uploads to Google Photos.\"\n\nClearly, this is going to be something we'll have to see for ourselves, because plenty of phones can livestream, while Samsung has offered the ability to record from both cameras at the same time for years, but it does sound like streaming both cameras live at the same time is new, so that will be interesting to check out when the opportunity arises.\n\nWe're also going to have to hear for ourselves the difference, as Nokia is talking up its OZO Audio technology, which it bills as \"placing exclusive Hollywood technology in the palm of your hand.\"\n\nThe deeper explanation is that \"OZO spatial 360\u00b0 audio brings a fully immersive audio experience to your 4K video,\" combining \"three microphones with exclusive Nokia acoustic algorithms to capture audio with immersive 360\u00b0 spatial surround sound,\" delivering \"leading-edge 360\u00b0 audio capture that \"ensures the playback lets you truly relive the moment so your memories never fade.\"\n\nNext up comes Nokia proudly boasting the 8 has \"a seamless unibody that is 4.6mm thin at the edge and just 7.3mm slim on average,\" and which is \"precision milled from a single block of 6000 series aluminium,\" with Nokia stating the app has claimed \"pure design\" that has been \"refined through a 40-stage process of machining, anodising and polishing.\"\n\nThere are clearly different finishes, with \"select models\" available that \"feature a high-gloss mirror finish that has taken over 20 hours to complete to achieve a flawless look.\"\n\nWith the result being \"a full-length, graphite shielded, copper cooling pipe that dissipates the heat generated by the high performing system across the full length and breadth of the handset,\" Nokia will be pleased now they have a The Nokia 8 runs cooler in even the most demanding situations.\n\nThe is meant to deliver a result of \"a full-length, graphite shielded, copper cooling pipe that dissipates the heat generated by the high performing system across the full length and breadth of the handset,\" with the Nokia 8 to run to: cooler in even the most demanding situations.\n\nThe Nokia is powered by Qualcomm's Snapdragon 835 processor and platform, Mobile Platform and paired with \"pure and secure\" Android 7.1.1, but no word on how quickly the update to Android OS 8.0 will arrive - although we are told there will be \"monthly security updates.\"\n\nThe pure Android experience is supposed to mean \"no unnecessary apps slowing down the performance of your device,\" along with \"monthly security updates\" so your Nokia 8 is \"safe and up-to-date,\" while \"biometric fingerprint authentication\" delivers enhanced security you expect from a flagship.\n\nThere's also \"Quick Charge 3.0 compatible\" for faster charging.\n\nJuho Sarvikas, Chief Product Officer of HMD Global, said: \"We know that fans are creating and sharing live content more than ever before, with millions of photos and videos shared every minute on social media. People are inspired by the content they consume and are looking for new ways to create their own.\n\n\"It's these people who have inspired us to craft a flagship smartphone which perfectly balances premium design, an outstanding experience and powerful performance.\"\n\nMark Trundle, General Manager ANZ of HMD Global, said: \"We saw how much Australian's love the Nokia brand when we announced the Nokia 3, Nokia 5 and Nokia 6 smartphones, and are now excited to launch our flagship handset - the Nokia 8 into the Australian market.\n\n\"Maintaining Nokia's craftsmanship and quality, we've built on our outstanding design with a pure Android experience to create a superior device featuring ZEISS optics, Dual-Sight live streaming capabilities and Nokia OZO spatial 360\u00b0 audio to allow consumers to create, share and enjoy content like never before.\"\n\nAvailable to pre-order from JB Hi Fi Friday 18 August, Nokia 8 will be available for a RRP of $899.00 at JB Hi Fi and Harvey Norman.\n\nChipset: Qualcomm\u00ae Snapdragon 835 Mobile Platform\n\nMSM8998 (4* 2.45GHz Qualcomm\u00ae KryoTM + 4* 1.8GHz Kryo)\n\nRAM: 4GB\n\nStorage: 64GBiii internal memory with external MicroSD card slot (support up to 256 GB)\n\nForm factor: Splashproof IP54 touch monoblock with capacitive system keys\n\nDisplay: 5.3\" IPS LCD QHD 2560 x 1440, 700nts screen brightness, Corning\u00ae facing camera: 13MP PDAF, 1.12um, f/2.0, 78.4 \u030a, display flash\n\nConnectivity & Sensors: Type C, USB3.1 Gen 1 (5Gbps), 3.5mm headphone jack, Ambient light sensor, Proximity sensor, Accelerometer, E-compass, Gyroscope, Fingerprint Sensor, Hall sensor, Barometer, 802.11 a/b/g/n/ac (MIMO), BT 5.0, GPS/AGPS+GLONASS+BDS, NFC, ANT+\n\nBattery: Integrated 3090 mAh batteryiv with {"timeCrawl": "18:58:00", "uri": "710494504", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:58:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4796976/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "HELSINKI, Aug 16 (Reuters) - HMD Global, the Finnish start-up looking to reinvigorate the Nokia phone brand, unveiled the Nokia 8 on Wednesday, hoping to cash in on rising consumer demand for high-quality audio and video features.\n\nThe Android device, due out in September, will potentially beat rivals on price but will still face fierce competition, with Apple's highly anticipated 10th anniversary iPhone also expected next month and Samsung's Galaxy Note 8 set to hit the market next week.\n\nWith a suggested price tag of around 599 euros ($703), the Nokia 8 undercuts Apple, which typically offers a stripped down version of its latest phones for a similar price but charges hundreds of euros more for memory and key features.\n\nThe new top-of-the-line Nokia sports a dual-sight video feature which enables simultaneous live-streaming on social media networks from both front and rear cameras on a split screen. It has licensed lens technology from camera maker Zeiss.\n\nIt is the most high-end phone so far from HMD, which was set up late last year and made a splash in May when it revived Nokia's classic 3310 feature handset in new brightly coloured versions.\n\nOther features of the Nokia 8, which will also compete with Huawei's recently launched P10, include surround-sound audio technology made for Nokia's own virtual reality camera OZO for Hollywood professionals.\n\n\"This is especially meant for millennial creators, people who want to share what's happening every day,\" HMD's chief marketing officer Pekka Rantala said.\n\nHMD products are built by a unit of Foxconn, which acquired the manufacturing and distribution assets of the former Nokia phone business from Microsoft last year.\n\nOnce the world's dominant phonemaker, Nokia Oyj sold its handset operations to Microsoft in 2014, leaving it to focus on telecoms network equipment.\n\nHMD is owned by Smart Connect LP, a private equity fund managed by Jean-Francois Baril, a long-serving former senior vice president of Nokia. It took over the Nokia feature phones business in December and has a licensing deal giving it sole use of the Nokia brand on all phones and tablets.\n\nIt has so far launched four smartphones and five feature phones, including the 3310. [nL5N1GB0JW}\n\nRantala said he was happy with initial sales of the previous smartphones, but declined to disclose any sales figures yet.\n\nHMD will pay Nokia royalties for the brand and patents.\n\nLast month, HMD announced that its CEO Arto Nummela, a former Nokia executive, was leaving the company for personal reasons, without elaborating. {"timeCrawl": "13:51:00", "uri": "710915671", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:20:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"title": "http://www.hindustantimes.com/", "uri": "hindustantimes.com", "id": "294"}, "url": "http://www.hindustantimes.com/gadgets/nokia-8-attempt-by-hmd-global-to-breathe-life-into-brand-that-once-dominated-market/story-wLLZkRST2pWYjTt76NgNdO.html", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "A new Nokia 8 phone is seen in this HMD Global handout picture obtained by Reuters.(Reuters)\n\nFinnish start-up HMD Global is looking to breathe life into the Nokia phone brand by unveiling the Nokia 8, with hopes to cash in on rising consumer demand for high-quality audio and video features.\n\nAvailable in four colours -- polished blue, polished copper, tempered blue and steel - the flagship phone will be available at the global price of 599 euros ($705) through September, the company said.\n\nThe device boasts three industry-first features for Android smartphones, including a collaboration with ZEISS optics, Nokia 'OZO Audio' and 'Dual-Sight' mode. With only 4.6mm thin at the edge and 7.3mm slim on average, the flagship device's unibody is made from 6000 series aluminium with select models featuring a high-gloss mirror finish.\n\nThe Android device, due out in September, will potentially beat rivals on price but will still face fierce competition, with Apple's highly anticipated 10th anniversary iPhone also expected next month and Samsung's Galaxy Note 8 set to hit the market next week.\n\nBut apart from trying to rival Apple and Samsung, the company has another challenge at hand: fighting the brand's tumultuous past. Here is Nokia's story so far, as tracked in a piece by The Guardian:\n\nNokia dominated the mobile phone market for the more than a decade from the late 1990s, but was left trailing behind Apple and Samsung in the smartphone era following the launch of the iPhone in 2007. The Finnish company sold its loss-making mobile devices division to Microsoft in 2013 to focus on its telecoms network equipment business.\n\nNow a group of former Nokia executives, backed by private equity, have formed the new company HMD Global and bought back their former employer's feature phone business from Microsoft , aiming to bring the Nokia handset brand back to its former glory with a range of new smartphones.\n\nNokia was founded in 1865 as a pulp mill near the town of Tampere and once made everything from toilet paper to car tyres, before the Espoo-headquartered company moved in to communications technology in the 1980s. In 1985 Nokia launched its first mobile phone, the Mobira Talkman, but it was 1987's Cityman which shot to fame when pictured in use by Mikhail Gorbachev.\n\nBy 1998, Nokia had overtaken mobile phone pioneer Motorola to become the bestselling global mobile phone brand, manufacturing its 100-millionth phone by December that year, with revenues of $20bn (then \u00a313bn) and 55,000 staff by the year 2000.\n\nThe Nokia 3310 was launched in 2000, with the world's bestselling phone of all time, the Nokia 1100, appearing in 2003. Nokia also launched the first camera phone in the US in 2003, partnering with the German optics manufacturer Carl Zeiss in 2005.\n\nNokia launched the world's first smartphone in 1996 - the Nokia 9000 Communicator - and a series of popular smartphones using its Symbian operating system followed in the early 2000s. But Nokia's long slide from relevance started with the launch of Apple's iPhone, which used superior touchscreen technology and left the Finnish firm's keypad-based handsets looking decidedly vintage.\n\nNokia struggled to make competitive Symbian-based smartphones and in 2011 partnered with Microsoft to develop handsets using the Windows Phone operating system, such as the Lumia 800. But with shrinking market share and mounting losses, Nokia bowed out of the mobile handset business two years later. Microsoft discontinued the Nokia brand for mobile phones in November 2014.", "id": "9702182", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Nokia 8: Attempt by HMD Global to breathe life into brand {"timeCrawl": "12:45:00", "uri": "710882253", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:45:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "uri": "dnaindia.com", "id": "492"}, "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/mobile/report-hmd-launches-nokia-8-here-s-what-to-expect-from-the-company-s-flagship-android-phone-2533029", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "HMD Global's Nokia 8 flagship smartphone will be available globally in early September.\n\nThe much-rumoured Nokia 8 was made official last night in London. HMD Global's smartphone comes with premium design, top-of-the-line specifications, and it will be competing against other flagship devices in the high-end segment. The Nokia 8 is priced at \u20ac599 (approximately Rs 45,000), and is set to go on sale globally early September. Some of the publications got hands-on time with the new Nokia 8, and here's a look at their first impressions.\n\nSince the launch of the first Nokia-branded Android smartphones, HMD Global hasn't stopped highlighting the design. With the Nokia 8 it is no different either. As Pocket-lint puts it, \"The Nokia 8 starts life as a block of aluminium, hewn into smartphone form, with a soft curve across the back and rounded edges to make it sit comfortably in the hand.\"\n\nThe Nokia 8 will be available in four colors - Polished Blue, Polished Copper, Tempered Blue, and Steel. Two of the colors come with a glossy finish, while the other two come with a less glamorous matt finish, albeit with more grip. \"It's particularly smart of Nokia to let customers choose between matt and polished finishes - we like that a lot - because while the polished finish looks more striking, the matt finishes offer more grip. It's a tough choice, but good to let consumers make that decision,\" T3 says.\n\nUnder the hood is Qualcomm's latest Snapdragon 835 SoC paired with 4GB of RAM. On paper at least the smartphone seems more than capable of handling any and every task thrown at it, and early impressions across publications are in line with that. What also aids in good performance is the fact that the Nokia 8 runs on stock Android 7.1.1 out-of-the-box. The company has promised Android O update as soon as Google rolls it out.\n\nWhat's caught everyone's eye is however the cooling system underneath. HMD Global says that Nokia 8 comes with graphite shielded copper cooling pipes that dissipate heat across the length and breadth of the handset. As GSMArena notes, \"...we want to commend HMD on how cool the Nokia 8 runs. The heat pipe and graphite shield must be doing some work as we re-ran multiple benchmarks in quick succession and the phone didn't even feel warm. Seriously, we can't tell where the chipset is by feel (usually, it's obvious on phones with poor heat management).\"\n\nAmong the highlights of the Nokia 8 is the dual-camera setup at the back, and the smartphone is being touted as one that is aimed at content creators. The setup includes a pair of 13-megapixel snappers - one shoots in RGB, and one in monochrome. The camera has been developed in partnership with Carl ZEISS. But the company is focusing on a feature it calls 'Bothie'. In essence, the Nokia 8 camera lets users shoot photos or videos using both the front and back cameras simultaneously. There is also a feature to livestream on social media directly from the camera app.\n\nThe dual-camera setup, and the Bothie feature is clearly designed with the over-sharing millennials in mind. \"The focus on livestreaming underscores where the new Nokia is headed as it targets a younger crowd more likely to use the feature on Snapchat or Instagram,\" Cnet says. \"It marks the latest comeback attempt from the brand, which was once the largest phone maker in the world by far but was ultimately crushed by newer players like Apple, Google and Samsung.\"\n\nSo far, early impressions about the Nokia 8 have been quite positive. But we will get a closer look at how good the smartphone is, once the first reviews are out. {"timeCrawl": "18:47:00", "uri": "710489546", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:47:00Z", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "source": {"title": "Pocket-lint", "uri": "pocket-lint.com", "id": "3699"}, "url": "http://www.pocket-lint.com/news/141812-nokia-8-vs-samsung-galaxy-s8-what-s-the-difference", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Nokia has announced a fourth Android smartphone to its 2017 portfolio. The company, which is now under the brand HMD Global, announced the Nokia 3, Nokia 5 and Nokia 6 in March but the true flagship contender comes in the form of the Nokia 8.\n\nHow does the Nokia 8 compare to its tough competition though? We have put the company's flagship device up against the Android smartphone king - the Samsung Galaxy S8 - to see how the two devices stack up against each other.\n\nThe Nokia 8 comes complete with rounded corners, a softly-curved back and a premium metal design that oozes quality. It will be available in polished copper, polished blue, a matt temperate blue and a steel finish.\n\nIt measures 151.5 x 73.7 x 7.9mm and it features minimal branding, a rectangular button on the front below the screen that doubles up as fingerprint sensor, and a slim vertical dual-camera and flash array on the rear. The Nokia 8's display has very slim bezels on the sides, but quite large bezels at the top and bottom.\n\nThe Samsung Galaxy S8 features a metal and glass design with exceptionally slim bezels surrounding the dual-edged display. It's almost all-screen on the front, with no physical buttons in sight, while the rear has a single-lens camera with a flash module to the left and a rectangular fingerprint sensor to the right.\n\nSamsung's smaller flagship measures 148.9 x 68.1 x 8.0mm and it hits the scales at 155g, making it smaller than the Nokia 8. The Galaxy S8 has IP68 water and dust resistance, something not specified for the Nokia 8, and it delivers an overall fabulous design that is available in six colour options.\n\nThere was talk of the Nokia 8 appearing in two sizes, like the S8 does, but instead it arrives in just one 5.3-inch screen size featuring a standard 16:9 aspect ratio, which is why it sits within a larger footprint than the S8 despite a smaller screen.\n\nNokia opts for an LCD display, coupled with a Quad HD resolution at 2560 x 1440, which puts the new flagship's pixel density at 554ppi. Nothing has been mentioned Mobile HDR compliancy so we assume it isn't on the new device but there is Corning Gorilla Glass 5 protection is on board.\n\nThe Samsung Galaxy S8 features a 5.8-inch display within its relatively small footprint, thanks to its 18.5:9 aspect ratio. As we briefly mentioned previously, the S8 has a dual-edge display, making it more exciting than some flat-display devices, while it also offers Mobile HDR Premium technology.\n\nIn terms of resolution, the Galaxy S8 opts for Quad HD+, which translates to 2960 x 1440 for a pixel density of 570ppi, making it slightly sharper than the Nokia 8. Samsung also uses Super AMOLED panels in its flagship devices, meaning punchy, vibrant colours, even if not as realistic as LCD.\n\nThe Nokia 8 comes complete with dual 13-megapixel rear cameras, along with a 13-megapixel front camera, all of which feature Zeiss lenses. The rear cameras are made up of one RGB sensor and one monochrome sensor, like the Huawei P10, and they offer an aperture of f/2.0 and phase detection autofocus, as does the front camera.\n\nNokia has also launched a Dual-Sight camera mode on the Nokia 8, which allows users to use both the front and rear cameras simultaneously in order to capture a photo or video of both yourself and the subject to then upload to a social media platform like Facebook or YouTube.\n\nMeanwhile, the Samsung Galaxy S8 doesn't opt for a dual-rear camera setup. Instead, there is a 12-megapixel single lens rear camera with a f/1.7 aperture lens, optical image stabilisation and 8x digital zoom.\n\nThe front camera has an 8-megapixel sensor, also with an aperture of f/1.7 and it comes with autofocus. Both the front and rear cameras of the S8 produce excellent results so even if it wins the megapixel battle, the Nokia 8 has a big task ahead in terms of camera capability.\n\nThe Nokia 8 comes with the Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 platform under its hood, coupled with 4GB of RAM and 64GB of internal storage. Like the existing Nokia Android phones, the Nokia 8 also comes with a microSD slot for storage expansion.\n\nBattery capacity sits at 3090mAh, is non-removable and charged via USB Type-C with Quick Charge 3.0 supported. There is also a 3.5mm headphone jack at the top of the Nokia 8 and the device features Ozo audio that binaurally encodes the surround sound it captures so it will be available to everyone.\n\nThe Samsung Galaxy S8 runs on either the Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 processor, or the Exynos 8895, depending on the region. Both devices come with 4GB of RAM, 64GB of storage and they both have microSD support for storage expansion up to 256GB.\n\nThe S8 has a battery capacity of 3000mAh, a little smaller than the Nokia 8 and Galaxy S8+ that has 3500mAh, and it too is charged via USB Type-C. The S8 also has a 3.5mm headphone jack and it supports 32-bit audio playback.\n\nThe current Nokia Android phones all run on pure Android Nougat with Google Assistant and the Nokia 8 does the same.\n\nAside from a tweaked camera, there is no bloatware or pre-installed apps, aside from a support app, and Nokia has said it is aiming for the Nokia 8 to be one of the first devices to offer Android O.\n\nThe Samsung Galaxy S8 on the other hand, runs on Android Nougat with Samsung's TouchWiz user interface over the top. That means you'll get more bloatware on the Samsung than the Nokia and therefore a different experience, but the S8 interface is great.\n\nThe Nokia 8 will go on sale globally in early September for \u20ac599, which is around \u00a3550.\n\nThe Samsung Galaxy S8 is available now and costs \u00a3689, making it quite a bit more expensive than Nokia's new flagship.\n\nThe Nokia 8 and the Samsung Galaxy S8 both offer premium designs and flagship specs.\n\nThe Nokia 8 doesn't have as large a display as the S8, nor does it offer the latest technology like Mobile HDR, but it is a slimmer device overall, it offers a pure Android software experience with quick updates likely and it has a dual-camera setup on the rear.\n\nThe Samsung Galaxy S8 on the other hand has a larger, sharper display, a design that could be considered more exciting and although a single rear camera lens, it's an excellent one.\n\nThe decision between these two handsets will likely come down to budget, as well as which design tickles your fancy more, as well as which features matter to you most. we will update this feature when we have reviewed the Nokia 8.", "id": "9544640", "details": {}, "date": It has licensed lens technology from camera maker Zeiss.\n\nIt is the most high-end phone so far from HMD, which was set up late last year and made a splash in May when it revived Nokia's classic 3310 feature handset in new brightly coloured versions.\n\nOther features of the Nokia 8, which will also compete with Huawei's recently launched P10, include surround-sound audio technology made for Nokia's own virtual reality camera OZO for Hollywood professionals.\n\n\"This is especially meant for millennial creators, people who want to share what's happening every day,\" HMD's chief marketing officer Pekka Rantala said.\n\nHMD products are built by a unit of Foxconn, which acquired the manufacturing and distribution assets of the former Nokia phone business from Microsoft last year.\n\nOnce the world's dominant phonemaker, Nokia Oyj sold its handset operations to Microsoft in 2014, leaving it to focus on telecoms network equipment.\n\nHMD is owned by Smart Connect LP, a private equity fund managed by Jean-Francois Baril, a long-serving former senior vice president of Nokia. It took over the Nokia feature phones business in December and has a licensing deal giving it sole use of the Nokia brand on all phones and tablets.\n\nIt has so far launched four smartphones and five feature phones, including the 3310. [nL5N1GB0JW}\n\nRantala said he was happy with initial sales of the previous smartphones, but declined to disclose any sales figures yet.\n\nHMD will pay Nokia royalties for the brand and patents.\n\nLast month, HMD announced that its CEO Arto Nummela, a former Nokia executive, was leaving the company for personal reasons, without elaborating. {"timeCrawl": "16:44:00", "uri": "711001519", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T11:15:00Z", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "source": {"title": "Sun.Star", "uri": "sunstar.com.ph", "id": "2809"}, "url": "http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/lifestyle/2017/08/17/nokia-8-three-firsts-one-precision-designed-flagship-559023", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "- First new generation Nokia smartphone to feature ZEISS optics\n\n- Tell both sides of the story with real-time live streaming using Dual-Sight mode\n\n- Introducing Nokia OZO spatial 360\u00b0 audio\n\nHMD Global, the home of Nokia phones, today announced the Nokia 8, a high performance, beautifully crafted smartphone, designed with content creators in mind. The Nokia 8 brings three world-firsts to Android smartphones, including a debut collaboration with ZEISS optics. With performance and pure Android at its heart, as well as the most advanced aluminium unibody design to date, the Nokia 8 represents all the hallmarks of a true flagship Nokia smartphone.\n\nBe less Selfie, be more Bothie: The Nokia 8 introduces a world-first in enabling Dual-Sight video to be livestreamed natively and in real-time to social feeds such as Facebook and YouTube. Dual-Sight simultaneously harnesses both the front and rear cameras in a split screen visual for both photos and videos. With just one touch, this world-first livestream capability gives more immersive experiences for those who love to create and share special memories.\n\nNokia 8 is also the first smartphone to feature Nokia OZO Audio, placing exclusive Hollywood technology in the palm of your hand. OZO spatial 360\u00b0 audio brings a fully immersive audio experience to your 4K video. Leading-edge 360\u00b0 audio capture ensures the playback lets you truly relive the moment so your memories never fade.\n\n4.6mm thin at the edge and just 7.3mm slim on average, Nokia 8's seamless unibody is precision milled from a single block of 6000 series aluminium and its pure design has been refined through a 40-stage process of machining, anodizing and polishing. Select models feature a high-gloss mirror finish that has taken over 20 hours to complete to achieve a flawless look. The phone features Qualcomm's powerful SnapdragonTM 835 Mobile Platform and paired with the pure, secure and up to date Android experience ensures outstanding performance.\n\nBe less Selfie, be more #Bothie\n\nThere are two sides to every story and the Dual-Sight feature of Nokia 8 is designed to help you create and share the full picture. The front and rear-facing cameras on the Nokia 8 have been co-developed with ZEISS optics for an optimum all round experience. Content creators can natively broadcast their unique #Bothie stories to social media through the Dual-Sight functionality located within the camera app. Fans can also enjoy unlimited[i] photo and video uploads to Google Photos.\n\nA new dimension of sound with OZO Audio\n\nFeaturing OZO Audio, Nokia 8 combines three microphones with exclusive Nokia acoustic algorithms to capture audio with immersive 360\u00b0 spatial surround sound. Share your 4K videos with OZO Audio anywhere - binaural codecs enable high fidelity playback even on devices without OZO Audio.\n\nInnovation and precision engineering\n\nPowered by the Qualcomm\u00ae SnapdragonTM 835 Mobile Platform, Nokia 8 doesn't compromise on performance.\n\nThe Nokia 8 has been designed from the ground up with the consumer in mind to deliver unique content capture and sharing experiences. This requires it to be as meticulously designed on the inside as it is on the outside. To keep your phone working harder for longer, the design, innovation and engineering teams worked hand-in-hand to deliver. The result is a full-length graphite shielded copper cooling pipe that dissipates the heat generated by the high performing system across the full length and breadth of the handset. The Nokia 8 runs cooler in even the most demanding situations.\n\nNokia 8 is Qualcomm\u00ae Quick ChargeTM 3.0 compatible, meaning when your battery is running low you can get back to recording your important moments sooner.\n\nJuho Sarvikas, Chief Product Officer of HMD Global, said:\n\n\"We know that fans are creating and sharing live content more than ever before, with millions of photos and videos shared every minute on social media. People are inspired by the content they consume and are looking for new ways to create their own. It's these people who have inspired us to craft a flagship smartphone which perfectly balances premium design, an outstanding experience and powerful performance.\"\n\nAlways pure Android\n\nNokia smartphones always offer a pure Android experience, with no unnecessary apps slowing down the performance of your device. And with Nokia 8, pure Android combined with our innovative engineering processes unleashes the full potential of the SnapdragonTM 835 Mobile Platform. With monthly security updates, the Nokia 8 is safe and up-to-date. Your device is secured with biometric fingerprint authentication, delivering enhanced security and making Nokia 8 a versatile companion whatever your needs.\n\nAccessories\n\nWe offer a range of accessories perfectly tailored to suit the active lifestyle of any Nokia 8 owner. The Nokia 8 works beautifully with the Nokia Active Wireless Headset - a lightweight, water, sweat, and dust proof premium headset. Carved from aluminium for the perfect match, this headset features a beautiful diamond cut design. The full portfolio of accessories for Nokia phones includes a range of headsets, portable speakers, in-car chargers, cases and screen protectors.\n\nAvailability\n\nNokia 8 will be available in four colours: Polished Blue, Polished Copper, Tempered Blue and Steel and will be available at a global average retail price of \u20ac599 with roll out throughout September. {"timeCrawl": "14:58:00", "uri": "710949098", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:58:00Z", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "source": {"title": "digitaljournal.com", "uri": "digitaljournal.com", "id": "556"}, "url": "http://www.digitaljournal.com/tech-and-science/technology/nokia-unveils-its-new-flagship-smartphone/article/500267", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Nokia has officially announced the Nokia 8, the company's anticipated flagship Android phone. Since the brand returned to the smartphone market this year, it has concentrated on the mid-range sector. It's now turning its sights towards a premium product. The Nokia 8 is a phone designed for content creators, according to its own creator HMD Global. As with all the new Nokia Android phones, the handset isn't really built by the Finnish name. Chinese manufacturer HMD is behind the device but it has worked closely with the Nokia company to develop its design and features. This is most evident in one of the 8's headline hardware capabilities. It comes with support for Nokia OZO Audio, a spatial 360-degree sound solution derived from Nokia's innovative OZO camera. The Nokia 8 will make 4K video more immersive by including spatial sound, offering more accurate replication of the environment where it was shot. It uses three microphones and Nokia's acoustic algorithms to create the videos. They can be played on any device, including ones without OZO Audio built-in. READ NEXT: Next year's high-end smartphones might have AR as standard Design-wise, the Nokia 8 continues HMD's trend of blending classic Nokia lines with contemporary counterparts from the smartphone industry. The phone is built from an aluminium unibody which is passed through a 40-stage anodizing and polishing process. It incorporates a graphite shielded cooling pipe to dissipate heat and is available with an optional glossy mirror finish. The phone is 7.3mm thick at its highest point, tapering to 4.6mm at the sides. Underneath, Nokia has included a typical hardware configuration for 2017's flagship phones. The 8 has a Qualcomm Snapdragon 835, 4GB of RAM, 64GB of expandable storage and an array of supporting hardware including a fingerprint sensor and USB Type-C. Both the primary and front cameras have 13MP sensors. A large 3,090mAh battery completes the package. HMD said the Nokia 8 is supposed to reflect the trends in mobile use towards ephemeral and live content. By creating a device focused on video, sound and streaming, it wants to appeal to people who use their phone to capture the world around them. With only a 5.3-inch QHD display, it's still relatively compact though, preserving a true mobile experience. READ NEXT: Samsung says the Galaxy Note 8 will 'do bigger things' \"We know that fans are creating and sharing live content more than ever before, with millions of photos and videos shared every minute on social media. People are inspired by the content they consume and are looking for new ways to create their own,\" said HMD Global Chief Product officer Juho Sarvikas. \"It's these people who have inspired us to craft a flagship smartphone which perfectly balances premium design, and outstanding experience and powerful performance.\" The Nokia 8 will launch in September with an expected retail price of \u20ac599, varying by market. Four colours, Polished Blue, Polished Copper, Tempered Blue and Steel, will be available. Like Nokia's other Android phones to date, the 8 runs a stock version of the operating system and comes with monthly security updates. HMD said the use of Android 7.1.1 Nougat in an unaltered form offers a \"pure\" experience that makes the phone \"a versatile companion.\"", "id": "9715691", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", comes with one very unusual feature.\n\nThe new device, which the firm said will cost \u20ac599 (\u00a3546), comes with split screen camera feature called Dual Sight which combines a photo or video from the front and rear-facing cameras at the same time.\n\nThe result is what Nokia is calling a \"Bothie\", which the company hopes will offer a new take on selfies.\n\nThe Nokia brand is now under licence to Finnish start-up HMD Global, which sparked the firm's revival earlier this year with the launch of three mid-range Android phones - the Nokia 3,5 and 6, as well as a revamped version of the 17-year-old 3310.\n\nThe flagship Nokia 8 features dual 13-megapixel rear cameras, as well as a 13-megapixel front-facing camera, while both the front and rear cameras feature optics technology from imaging giant Zeiss, who announced a new partnership with Nokia and HMD Global last month.\n\nZeiss technology is also being used to help improve the quality of photos taken on the 8, Nokia said, with \"image fusion algorithms\" in place to combine images captured by the two rear lenses into single photos.\n\nThe new phone also houses spatial audio technology previously only used in Nokia's high-end OZO 360 camera, which can play back sound in multiple directions, imitating how it was captured during recording.\n\nThe phone's specifications place it as a rival to the likes of Apple's iPhone 7 and Samsung's Galaxy S8 in the current smartphone market.\n\nHMD Global confirmed the phone will go on sale in \"early September\" and said the device was aimed at social media users and video creators.\n\n\"We know that fans are creating and sharing live content more than ever before, with millions of photos and videos shared every minute on social media,\" HMD chief product officer
