{"timeCrawl": "06:26:00", "uri": "710712894", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T06:26:00Z", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "source": {"title": "indiatimes.com", "uri": "indiatimes.com", "id": "6718"}, "url": "http://www.indiatimes.com/technology/gadgets/nokia-8-wants-to-introduce-you-to-a-bothie-very-soon-make-you-fall-in-love-with-it-327983.html", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Like a phoenix rising from the ashes, Nokia's return to the world of smartphones is almost complete. The phone it announced last night completes its modern reincarnation, which began at Mobile World Congress earlier this year.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is the HMD Global-owned brand's answer to the likes of Samsung Galaxy S8, OnePlus 5, Google Pixel XL and iPhone 7 Plus. And its pi\u00e8ce de r\u00e9sistance for now seems to be the 'bothie'.\n\nIt's not as self-obsessed as a selfie, that's what a bothie is. Where most smartphone cameras only let you shoot video from either its front or rear camera, at any given time, the Nokia 8 will allow you to shoot and stream live videos on Facebook and YouTube that turns on and captures video from both its front and rear camera.\n\nDual-Sight, to give bothie its proper technical term, is capable of capturing 4K widescreen videos from both cameras simultaneously, dividing the screen into two halves, where you can simultaneously view the selfie video side-by-side with the rear video. Pretty cool or completely pointless? The jury's out on that one. But apart from its unimaginative nomenclature, a bothie's success or failure will heavily depend on how entrenched Nokia 8 buyers will be on the online social circuit.\n\nBesides bothie, the Nokia 8 has several other talking points. It marks the return of Zeiss lenses in the smartphone fold, something that past Nokia phones were renowned for.\n\nThe Nokia 8 sports a unibody 6000 aluminium series shell, with four colour options with two matte and two glossy versions. It can withstand just a few splashes of water, and it isn't advisable to take it for a full dip in the pool.\n\nThere are two 13MP cameras on the rear panel of the Nokia 8 -- one colour, one monochrome -- with support for optical image stabilisation, phase detection autofocus, and a wide f/2.0 aperture built into the camera optics. Like the current crop of Android flagships in the market, the Nokia 8 will also be capable of shooting good low-light shots with enhanced portrait capture mode.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is powered by the best smartphone chip in the market, the Qualcomm Snapdragon 835, which is paired with 4GB of RAM. HMD Global's making available both single SIM and dual SIM variants of the phone -- but watch out, the dual SIM version has a hybrid slot, which means you'll have to toss a coin between the microSD card and a double SIM. The Nokia 8's QHD 5.3-inch display sports a 2560\u00d71440 resolution and is shielded from knocks, bumps and scratches by Gorilla Glass 5.\n\nNokia 8 has a 3090mAh battery with Qualcomm's Quick Charge 3.0 support, and a USB-C port. It also comes with stock (bloatware-free) Android Nougat 7.1.1 baked in, and HMD Global claims it's going to be first smartphone to get Google's next Android O update. Thankfully, it also has a 3.5mm audio jack to plug in a headphone, if you wanted to.\n\nNokia 8 is also featuring Nokia OZO Audio, which brings OZO spatial 360\u00b0 audio to your 4K video. The technology has trickled down from old Nokia's OZO VR capture camera for professionals, and not for consumers. Thanks to high dynamic range microphones, the Nokia 8 will be able to capture distortion-free, spatial audio for enhanced immersiveness in 360\u00b0 videos.", "id": "9623760", "details": {}, "date": It has licensed lens technology from camera maker Zeiss.\n\nIt is the most high-end phone so far from HMD, which was set up late last year and made a splash in May when it revived Nokia's classic 3310 feature handset in new brightly coloured versions.\n\nOther features of the Nokia 8, which will also compete with Huawei's recently launched P10, include surround-sound audio technology made for Nokia's own virtual reality camera OZO for Hollywood professionals.\n\n\"This is especially meant for millennial creators, people who want to share what's happening every day,\" HMD's chief marketing officer Pekka Rantala said.\n\nHMD products are built by a unit of Foxconn, which acquired the manufacturing and distribution assets of the former Nokia phone business from Microsoft last year.\n\nOnce the world's dominant phonemaker, Nokia Oyj sold its handset operations to Microsoft in 2014, leaving it to focus on telecoms network equipment.\n\nHMD is owned by Smart Connect LP, a private equity fund managed by Jean-Francois Baril, a long-serving former senior vice president of Nokia. It took over the Nokia feature phones business in December and has a licensing deal giving it sole use of the Nokia brand on all phones and tablets.\n\nIt has so far launched four smartphones and five feature phones, including the 3310.\n\nRantala said he was happy with initial sales of the previous smartphones, but declined to disclose any sales figures yet.\n\nHMD will pay Nokia royalties for the He joined as a reporter in 2011 and covers all areas of IT, with a particular interest in telecommunications, mobile and networking, along with sports technology.\n\nNokia 8 is revived brand's attempt to capture high end market with premium exterior, immersive streaming and pure Android\n\nThe latest smartphone to bear the Nokia brand is banking on advanced imaging features and a polished exterior to help it crack the crowded Android market.\n\nHMD Global has released a number of devices under licence from Nokia, which focuses almost exclusively on networking equipment following the sale of its devices business to Microsoft in 2013, most notably the Nokia 3310 revival.\n\nHowever, the Nokia 8 is undeniably an attempt to capture high end demand. The headline feature of the 5.3 inch Nokia 8 is 'Dual Sight' streaming which pairs the rear and front 13 megapixel cameras to transmit two streams of live video for platforms like Facebook and YouTube.\n\nNokia 8 smartphone\n\nIndeed, the phone is fruit borne of HMD's partnership with ZEISS optics and this 'immersive' streaming is complemented by 360-degree Nokia OZO audio.\n\nUnder the bonnet is an octa-core Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 processor, 4GB of RAM, 64GB of internal storage (which can be supplemented by up to 256GB via the MicroSD card slot) and version 7.1.1 Nougat of stock Android.\n\nThe fact that the Nokia 8 runs a 'pure' version of the operating system rather than the customised variants served up Samsung, HTC and others is being heavily pushed by HMD which claims the arrival of monthly security updates will protect it from the threats that plague the platform.\n\nWhat is your biggest cybersecurity concern?\n\nRansomware Humans / Social Engineering Out of date tools DDoS State sponsored hackers Malware Other\n\nView Results\n\nLoading ...\n\nThe final innovation HMD is touting is the aluminum unibody. The exterior is built from a single block of metal and the premium models of the phone have a 'high gloss mirror finish' that apparently takes 20 hours to complete.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is avaliable in 'polished' blue, 'polished' copper, standard blue and standard steel and will cost \u20ac599 when it is released.\n\n\"We know that fans are creating and sharing live content more than ever before, with millions of photos and videos shared every minute on social media,\" said Juho Sarvikas, chief product officer at HMD Global. \"People are inspired by the content they consume and are looking for new ways to create their own. It's these people who have inspired us to craft a flagship smartphone which perfectly balances premium design, an outstanding experience and powerful performance.\"\n\nAside from the Nokia 3310, HMD "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nNokia has unveiled its first flagship Android smartphone - the Nokia 8 - as the technology firm attempts to challenge the likes of Samsung and Apple for the first time.\n\nThe new device, which the firm said will cost \u00a3546, comes with split screen camera feature called Dual Sight which combines a photo or video from the front and rear-facing cameras at the same time.\n\nThe result is what Nokia is calling a \"Bothie\", which the company hopes will offer a new take on selfies.\n\nThe Nokia brand is now under license to Finnish start-up HMD Global, which sparked the firm's revival earlier this year with the launch of three mid-range Android phones - the Nokia 3,5 and 6, as well as a revamped version of the 17-year-old 3310.\n\nThe flagship Nokia 8 features dual 13-megapixel rear cameras, as well as a 13-megapixel front-facing camera, while both the front and rear cameras feature optics technology from imaging giant Zeiss, who announced a new partnership with Nokia and HMD Global last month.\n\nZeiss technology is also being used to help improve the quality of photos taken on the 8,Nokia said, with \"image fusion algorithms\" in place to combine images captured by the two rear lenses into single photos.\n\nThe new phone also houses spatial audio technology previously only used in Nokia's high-end OZO 360 camera, which can play back sound in multiple directions, imitating how it was captured during recording.\n\nThe phone's specifications place it as a rival to the likes of Apple's iPhone and Samsung's Galaxy S8 in the current smartphone market.\n\nHMD Global confirmed the phone will go on sale in \"early September\" and said the device was aimed at social media users and video creators.\n\n\"We know that fans are creating and sharing live content more than ever before, with millions of photos and videos shared every minute on social media,\" HMD chief product officer Juho Sarvikas said.\n\n\"People are inspired by the content they consume and are looking for new ways to create their own.\n\n\"It's these people who have inspired us to craft a flagship smartphone which perfectly balances premium design, an outstanding experience and powerful performance.\"\n\nLive video {"timeCrawl": "13:52:00", "uri": "710916199", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T17:20:00Z", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "source": {"title": "http://www.theinquirer.net", "uri": "theinquirer.net", "id": "2655"}, "url": "https://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/3015787/nokia-8-official", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "HMD GLOBAL has officially launched the Nokia 8, its first 'flagship' Android device.\n\nAs expected, the Nokia 8 packs a 5.3in QHD LCD display, and under the hood, you'll find Qualcomm's Snapdragon 835 processor, 4GB RAM and 64GB storage, which can be expanded via microSD. There's also a 3,090mAh battery, which HMD claims will get you more than a full day of usage, complete with support for Quick Charge 3.0.\n\nThere's a USB-C port on the bottom for charging, alongside a 3.5mm headphone jack.\n\nThe Nokia 8, which like its predecessors comes crafted from a single piece of aluminium, has shunned the recent shift towards bezel-less smartphones and comes equipped with a physical home button, which houses a baked-in fingerprint sensor.\n\nThe Nokia 8's standout feature, at least according to HMD Global, is its camera, as it's the first Android-powered Nokia phone to pack Carl Zeiss optics. There's a 13MP dual setup on the rear of the phone, which - much like the camera on the Huawei P10 - pairs RGB and monochrome sensors for better image quality. There's also a 13MP sensor on the front of the phone.\n\nHMD has added what it calls a \"bothie\" mode (ugh) that will activate both the front and rear cameras to capture phones and videos. Unlike the similar functionality found on Samsung smartphones, the Nokia 8 is also capable of broadcasting this video to Facebook or Youtube.\n\nHMD has also added Ozo Audio, which means that much like Nokia's futuristic VR camera, the Nokia 8 will capture 360-degree audio, allowing for it to be broadcast live on streams.\n\nJuho Sarvikas, chief product officer at HMD Global, swooned: \"We know that fans are creating and sharing live content more than ever before, with millions of photos and videos shared every minute on social media.\n\n\"People are inspired by the content they consume and are looking for new ways to create their own. It's these people who have inspired us to craft a flagship smartphone which perfectly balances premium design, an outstanding experience and powerful performance.\"\n\nThe Nokia 8 will ship running Android 7.1.1, and HMD has said that it'll be updated to Android O once it becomes available. At launch, it will be available in Polished Blue, Polished Copper, and Tempered Blue and Steel colour options.\n\nThe Nokia 8 will be available in Europe from September, and will fetch \u20ac599 (around \u00a3550) SIM-free. Exact UK pricing details have not yet been announced. \u00b5", "id": "9702385", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Nokia 8: Android 'flagship' official with Snapdragon 835, dual 13MP {"timeCrawl": "05:37:00", "uri": "710697562", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:37:00Z", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "source": {"title": "iGyaan Network", "uri": "igyaan.in", "id": "6649"}, "url": "http://www.igyaan.in/136802/nokia-8-launched/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "HMD Global has unveiled the first ever Nokia branded Android flagship, the Nokia 8 at an event in London on August 16th. The premium smartphone with an all metal design, dual cameras and more 2017 specifications will go on sale in early September for 599 Euros (Rs. 45,000 approx.). After a string of mid-range Android smartphones, the Nokia 8 was highly anticipated for not just being a Nokia flagship, but the first flagship device since the Finnish company's Windows Phone days.\n\nThe Nokia 8 has an IP54 rating for splash resistance. Although, the smartphone does not look like a 2017 flagship with big bezels around the edges unlike the LG G6 or the Samsung Galaxy S8/S8+. The Nokia 8 sports a 5.3 inch 2560 x 1440 px display and 2.5D Corning Gorilla Glass 5 for protection. Powering the device is a 3,090mAh battery with QuickCharge 3.0 support via USB Type-C port. Under the hood is the Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 chipset and a 2.45GHz octa-core processor, the Adreno 540 GPU, 4GB of RAM and 64GB of onboard storage which is expandable via microSD card. The Nokia 8 runs on stock Android 7.1.1 OS and the company has promised monthly security updates and yearly Android updates. The fingerprint sensor is housed inside the home button below the screen.\n\nThe new flagship is also the first Nokia Android device to feature Carl Zeiss optics. In a very 2017 move, the Nokia 8 boasts a Zeiss powered dual camera setup at the rear - a primary 13MP RGB (colour) sensor with optical image stabilisation paired with a 13MP secondary monochrome (black and white) sensor and an f/2.0 aperture. The dual-camera setup is capable of recording videos in 4K at 30 FPS and has a portrait mode for bokeh effect. On the front is a 13MP camera which can also record 4K videos at 30FPS.\n\nThe Nokia 8 comes with a feature called Bothie. It is the first smartphone in the world which allows 'Dual-Sight' video to be live streamed natively and in real-time to social feeds such as YouTube and Facebook. Dual-Sight allows you to use the front and rear camera at the same time in a split screen view. Another feature that the smartphone boasts is called OZO Audio in which the smartphone's three microphones and Nokia's acoustic algorithms allow you to capture 360-degree spatial surround sound. You can also share 4K videos with OZO audio with anyone - binaural codecs ensure high fidelity playback even on devices without OZO Audio.\n\nThere is no official word on the Nokia 8's availability in India as of yet. The Finnish brands' foray into Android smartphones has s far been through mid-rangers, but, with this flagship device, Nokia is ready to compete with the big boys of the smartphone industry.", "id": {"timeCrawl": "21:06:00", "uri": "710544214", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T21:06:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"title": "GSMArena.com", "uri": "gsmarena.com", "id": "2022"}, "url": "http://www.gsmarena.com/nokia_8_hands_on-review-1641.php", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "This is a Nokia phone built by Foxconn for HMD in partnership with Zeiss and Google. Make no mistake, though, there's Finnish blood running through Nokia 8's veins. The new leadership tried to resurrect the qualities that were vital to the Nokia brand: quality, simplicity, trust and reliability.\n\nWe were hoping for a camera phone and we got a camera phone. It's the first fruit of the reformed partnership with Zeiss. Nokia has its own camera division now, OZO, which was brought in to design the microphones and capturing algorithms for the phone.\n\nListening to HMD, it was easy to tell that that the camera is the differentiating feature of the Nokia 8. The target audience is people steeped in social networking, especially video content.\n\nThe phone shoots 4K video, naturally, and you can livestream it to YouTube and Facebook. A unique feature is picture-in-picture mode that shows footage from both the front and the back cameras - live! This will allow you to \"tell both sides of the story\".\n\nCamera aside, the Nokia 8 is built out of aluminum and glass and offers IP54 resistance. HMD did make it a bit on the small side for a flagship - most Android top dogs are well past a 5.3\" screen. Of course, some will view this as a good thing, not everyone wants a large phone.\n\nThe company tapped Qualcomm for the Snapdragon 835 chipset and Google for the software. Really, HMD and Nokia tinkered with some internals (especially relating to camera image and audio processing), but the Android OS is as it came out of the factory. That will allow for fast updates when the time comes.\n\nWell, this brings back memories of the metal-clad Nokia N8 and its awesome camera. {"timeCrawl": "05:17:00", "uri": "710689868", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T02:16:00Z", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "source": {"title": "Daily News", "uri": "nydailynews.com", "id": "422"}, "url": "http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/news/business/new-nokia-8-phone-targets-surging-demand-video-streaming-article-1.3418341", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "HELSINKI (Reuters) - HMD Global, the Finnish start-up looking to reinvigorate the Nokia phone brand, unveiled the Nokia 8 on Wednesday, hoping to cash in on rising consumer demand for high-quality audio and video features.\n\nThe Android device, due out in September, will potentially beat rivals on price but will still face fierce competition, with Apple's highly anticipated 10th anniversary iPhone also expected next month and Samsung's Galaxy Note 8 set to hit the market next week.\n\nWith a suggested price tag of around 599 euros ($703), the Nokia 8 undercuts Apple, which typically offers a stripped down version of its latest phones for a similar price but charges hundreds of euros more for memory and key features.\n\nThe new top-of-the-line Nokia sports a dual-sight video feature which enables simultaneous live-streaming on social media networks from both front and rear cameras on a split screen. It has licensed lens technology from camera maker Zeiss.\n\nIt is the most high-end phone so far from HMD, which was set up late last year and made a splash in May when it revived Nokia's classic 3310 feature handset in new brightly colored versions.\n\nOther features of the Nokia 8, which will also compete with Huawei's recently launched [HWT.UL] P10, include surround-sound audio technology made for Nokia's own virtual reality camera OZO for Hollywood professionals.\n\n\"This is especially meant for millennial creators, people who want to share what's happening every day,\" HMD's chief marketing officer Pekka Rantala said.\n\nHMD products are built by a unit of Foxconn, which acquired the manufacturing and distribution assets of the former Nokia phone business from Microsoft last year.\n\nOnce the world's dominant phonemaker, Nokia Oyj sold its handset operations to Microsoft in 2014, leaving it to focus on telecoms network equipment.\n\nHMD is owned by Smart Connect LP, a private equity fund managed by Jean-Francois Baril, a long-serving former senior vice president of Nokia. It took over the Nokia feature phones business in December and has a licensing deal giving it sole use of the Nokia brand on all phones and tablets.\n\nIt has so far launched four smartphones and five feature phones, including the 3310. [nL5N1GB0JW}\n\nRantala said he was happy with initial sales of the previous smartphones, but declined to disclose any sales figures yet.\n\nHMD will pay Nokia royalties for the brand and patents.\n\nLast month, HMD announced that its CEO Arto Nummela, a former Nokia executive, was leaving the company for personal reasons, without elaborating.\n\n(Reporting by Jussi Rosendahl and Eric Auchard; Editing by Susan Fenton)\n\n(c) Copyright Thomson Reuters 2017. {"timeCrawl": "18:55:00", "uri": "710493476", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:55:00Z", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "source": {"title": "The Register", "uri": "theregister.co.uk", "id": "853"}, "url": "https://www.theregister.co.uk/2017/08/16/nokia_8_review/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Hands On To understand the appeal of the first \"Nokia flagship\" in three years, the Nokia 8, think of what Google was doing with the Nexus line until it caught \"Pixelitis\"*. Stock Android, monthly updates, decent imaging, and competitively priced. And really no other frills or gimmicks.\n\nThe phone does have some Nokia DNA, as it was designed largely in London with a team comprised of several ex-Nokia designers, and it shows. While we're waiting for the UK SIM-free price to be clarified, a global average of \u20ac599 means it should be around \u00a3100 cheaper SIM-free than the HTC and LG rivals, and \u00a3150 cheaper than the Samsung Galaxy S8.\n\nNokia has gone for \"as close to stock as possible\" here. The Camera app is the only home-grown app on the device, although it's not the only unique technology. The USP is a treat for audiophiles - the phone will capture 360 surround sound in the manner of the \u00a350,000 stereoscopic OZO camera sold partner-not-parent Nokia. How \"in the manner of\" we'll have to see.\n\nOnly three years ago the old Nokia was packing some of its phones with a very impressive audio capture subsystem called HAAC (High Amplitude Audio Capture). The dynamic range was so wide it could pick up whispers on a noisy street, as trucks rolled past. Or, it could record a rock band while standing next to the speaker stack, without distortion. The HMD-era Nokia describes \"OZO Audio\" as a successor to HAAC, which certainly invites high expectations.\n\nHAAC used four custom microphones, while Nokia execs I spoke to merely pointed out that it had specified what mics hardware partner Foxconn should use.\n\nZeiss-certified lenses are back, and the phone will be able to live-stream from both main camera and front-facing camera simultaneously, while the camera shows social media updates. For DIY broadcasters this is great, but you wonder how many others care about taking split-screen (front and back) images or movies.\n\nMore practically, new Nokia claims to have worked hard to optimise battery life, with a liquid-cooling pipe. \"We can run the latest SD harder and longer than what you see on the marketplace today,\" execs told us. And it should boast superior RF, since the cellular antennae are at the top and bottom, rather than worked into the sides - easy to cover with your hands in normal use, hence \"the Death Grip\". In a preview, I found the \"aggressively\" (their description not mine) curved design made the 8 very comfortable to hold and use - and it has real captive buttons, so it doesn't force you to slide up a navigation bar manually.\n\nWhat are you missing?\n\nThe Nokia 8 is only \"splashproof\" to a IP54 standard, rather than the more demanding IP67 standards met by the iPhone 7, and even more demanding IP68 tests passed by the Samsung Galaxy S8, LG G6 and HTC U11. There's no wireless charging, something the former Nokia pioneered and used to differentiate itself in 2012, in its Lumias.\n\nHowever, as readers have pointed out under our OnePlus 5 review, cheaper-than-flagship is an unforgiving place to be. If you're going to be paying a lot for a phone, why not pay a bit more? For one reader a Samsung Galaxy \"was between 50 and 100 quid more but a quality brand, waterproof, better camera and post processing and nice looking screen\".\n\n\"Consumers simply aren't interested in expensive but not top-end phones. If they want an expensive phone, they're going to pay a little bit more to get all the bells and whistles available, while if they're happy to compromise on features they simply don't want to pay that much. There's a good market for \u00a3250 or so and lower phones, and a smaller but profitable market for high-end phones,\" concluded one.\n\nNokia hopes that they're wrong. \u00ae", "id": "9545923", {"timeCrawl": "11:18:00", "uri": "709725022", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T11:18:00Z", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "source": {"title": "coventrytelegraph", "uri": "coventrytelegraph.net", "id": "2070"}, "url": "http://www.coventrytelegraph.net/whats-on/whats-on-news/new-nokia-8-smartphone-iphone-13478473", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nNokia is due to unveil its new flagship smartphone on Wednesday, the company's first since making a comeback earlier this year.\n\nThe Finnish technology giant will reportedly announce the Nokia 8, a high specification device with dual rear cameras designed to rival those found on the iPhone 7 and other popular devices in the mobiles industry.\n\nThe Nokia brand was revived in the spring by Finnish start-up HMD Global - which is the exclusive licensee of the name.\n\nIn March as part of its comeback announcement, the company revealed a new version of its classic 3310 handset, as well as three new mid-range Android smartphones - theNokia 3, 5 and 6.\n\nHowever, the Nokia 8 will be the first device released by Nokia and HMD Global designed to be a rival to the iPhone, as well as other premium smartphones such as Samsung's Galaxy S8 and HTC's U11.\n\nAccording to early reports, the new Nokia 8 is expected to feature a Quad HD resolution display and dual rear cameras the feature technology from optics giant Carl Zeiss, who agreed a partnership with Nokia in July.\n\nNokia was one of the world's leading phone makers in the early 2000s thanks to popular handsets such as the 3310, but struggled to compete with the likes of Apple and Samsung once the era of touchscreen smartphones began in 2007.\n\nThe announcement takes place a week before Samsung is due to reveal the Galaxy Note 8, the first new Note device since the Korean firm was forced to recall and discontinue the Note 7 last year over safety concerns and battery fires.\n\nApple is expected to follow in early September with the announcement of the next version of the iPhone - with as many as three variants of the phone rumoured to be in production as the tech giant marks 10 years since the smartphone first launched.\n\nRead More Tuesday's must-read stories\n\nDownload our all-new mobile app to get the latest news, sport and what's on.\n\nOne quick sync and you can read our content on the move without being online.\n\nGet regular news alerts straight to your mobile and keep up with the latest traffic and travel or breaking events as they happen via our daily live blogs.\n\nIt's completely customisable to your own specific interests.\n\nDownload it today by clicking here for iPhone and here for Android\n\nLooking for an older story? The Nokia 8 features a 5.3-inch QHD display with a resolution of 2460\u00d71440. Under the hood is a Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 processor, and there are variants with either 4GB of RAM or 6GB of RAM and 64GB or 128GB of storage. There's a microSD card slot for expandable storage, too.\n\nThe Nokia 8 also features a 3090mAh battery, a USB Type-C port, and a 3.5mm headphone jack on board. Android 7.1.1 Nougat is on board, too, as well as a fingerprint reader for good measure.\n\nThe standout feature for this device is the pair of 13-megapixel cameras on the back, which features Carl ZEISS optics. Meanwhile, the front of the Nokia 8 features a 13-mgeapixel camera with PDAF.\n\nTied to the cameras is a new Dual-Sight mode, which allows the owner to take a photo or video using the front camera and the rear camera at the same time. Nokia calls this \"Bothies.\" The phone also features built- in live streaming to both YouTube Live and Facebook Live.\n\nThe Nokia 8 also features OZO spatial 360-degree audio, which HMD Global says \"accentuate the right sounds while reducing ambient sounds or background noise.\"\n\nThe Nokia 8's global launch will take place beginning in September and it'll be priced starting at \u20ac599 (about $703 USD). The phone has been spotted in live image leaks, in certifications and various other listings. However, after months of wait, the Nokia flagship is now official. The company announced the phone just hours ago, and here's a complete look at the specifications and the features of the Nokia 8:\n\nLet us take a look at the build and design quality, the features and the pricing of the latest Nokia flagship smartphone -\n\nNokia's latest smartphone, the Nokia 8 comes out into the markets with an impressive body. It features a slim, all-metal build. The phone measures about 4.6 inches thick at the edges, while the maximum thickness is seen in the area of the camera bump, where the phone measures about 7.9mm thick. Thankfully the 3.5mm jack is still there!\n\nIn the front, the phone features a front facing camera on the top along with the proximity sensor. It comes with narrow bezels on the top and the bottom. The top bezel carries the Nokia branding. On the bottom we see a fingerprint scanner that doubles up as the home button. Two capacitive keys are present on either side. The phone offers USB Type-C connectivity.\n\nOn the back it offers a dual camera, which is one of the highlights of this phone. We will discuss the camera in detail when addressing the specifications below. Overall, the build looks really good. The phone is made by HMD Global and has been officially launched just hours ago, after months of anticipation.\n\nNokia's latest flagship device comes out into the markets with a 5.3 inched 2K display. The phone comes out with an IPS LCD display, which offers a resolution of 2560 x 1440. The display is protected by a 2.5D Curved Corning Gorilla Glass 5 protection. The design of the display resembles that of the Nokia 6. It was a little disappointing that Nokia did not introduce edge to edge display in this flagship smartphone of theirs.\n\nThe Nokia 8 runs on the Snapdragon 835 processor along with the Adreno 540 GPU. The phone comes out into the markets in only one RAM/Storage variant - featuring 4GB of RAM along with 64GB of storage space. However, the storage can be expanded with the help of MicroSD cards. It can be expanded up to 256GB. The phone runs on the stock Android 7.1.1 Nougat OS.\n\nNokia 8's cameras are one of its highlights. The phone comes with two 13MP + 13MP Zeiss cameras present on the back. These back cameras feature one RGB Lens and another Monochrome lens. Together, these two knit an image which offers the truest color experience possible. The front camera also comes out with a 13MP lens.\n\nNokia has stated that the global average retail price for the phone would be around 599 Euros ($700). However, the final price might differ based on various taxes and other charges which vary from region to region. The phone comes out in four color variants: Blue Satin, Blue Polished, Steel, and Copper.\n\nMoreover, it is speculated that the Nokia 8 might not launch in China and the US (at least as of now), as HMD Global has logistics issues there. {"timeCrawl": "19:11:00", "uri": "710498457", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T19:11:00Z", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "source": {"title": "The Indian Express", "uri": "indianexpress.com", "id": "1155"}, "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/technology/mobile-tabs/nokia-8-launched-hmd-global-india-launch-price-specifications-features-details-4799704/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Written by Shruti Dhapola | London | Published:August 17, 2017 12:15 am Nokia 8 has been launched by HMG Global and the phone will be available in India by October. Nokia 8 launch today: Specifications, expected pricing and everything else to knowNokia 8 likely to be unveiled today as HMD Global gears up for flagship launchNokia 2 variants get FCC certifications: Launch to take place soon?\n\nNokia 8 flagship smartphone has been unveiled by HMD Global at an event in London. The new flagship phone will be available globally by September 2017, and is expected to retail at an average price of Euro 599, around Rs 45,000 on conversion. Nokia 8 will hit stores in India by early October, according to HMD Global's chief product officer Juho Sarvikas.\n\nNokia 8 is the new flagship smartphone from the company, and sports a 5.3-inch 2K LCD IPS display with 700 nits brightness, Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 processor coupled with 4GB RAM and 64GB of storage, which is expandable.\n\nThe phone has Gorilla Glass 5 on top and will launch with two glossy and two matte variants. The phone is launching in four colours: polished blue and copper which have a glossy finish, while there's the tempered blue and steel phones which have a matte finish. The new flagship is not entirely water and dust resistant, though it has an IP54 rating making it splash-proof.\n\nHMD Global will have dual-SIM and single-SIM variants of the Nokia 8 depending on the market. The dual-SIM slot is a hybrid one. HMD Global is not launching a 128GB variant of this phone for now. The battery is 3090 mAh, and there is support for USB 3.0 and fast charging with Quick Charge 3.0. With the design, Nokia 8 has a metal unibody design and muted antenna bands on top and a vertical rear camera setup.\n\nOn the software front, the company is sticking with its no-bloatware policy and the phone runs stock Android 7.1.1 version. Sarvikas said Nokia 8 would be the fastest way to get Android O. \"We are in a very advanced stage in Android O development. Of course, we are still waiting for some completion from the chipset vendor side, which in our case is Qualcomm. But we'll be one of the fastest to get Android O,\" he said.\n\nNokia 8 comes in four colour variants. This the polished copper variant\n\nThe new Nokia 8 also comes with a dual rear camera, the first to tout the Zeiss Optics branding since the relaunch. But there's a lot more going on here that just specifications. HMD Global has gone for a 13MP+ 13MP combination on the back with a monochrome and RGB sensor. The front camera is also 13MP with the same sensor being used as the one on the back. This one also has a Zeiss Optics branding, however, HMD Global is not revealing the actual vendor for the camera sensor. Both the front and back cameras will support 4K Video recording.\n\nNokia 8 has options for a dual-live stream with both the front and rear camera recording at the same time.\n\nHMD Global has also tweaked the camera software. The rear camera supports a 'bokeh' mode like many of the other dual cameras in the market. But the company has also added a feature for recording live videos from the native camera app. A user can stream live videos to Facebook, YouTube from the Nokia 8's camera app itself. There's also the option of having a dual-stream, where the front and rear camera can both be used at the same time in the live video. However, the dual feature won't work if you shoot the live video from the Facebook or YouTube app itself.\n\n\"Both cameras can be active at the same. A user will be able to tell both sides of the story. We also have the livestream option,\" explained Sarvikas on the reasoning behind this sort of feature in the camera. The Nokia 8 also comes with Ozo Audio and has high-dynamic range microphones. Ozo is the 360-degree virtual reality camera from the original Nokia firm. The company claims the phone is capturing surround audio which is then encoded with Ozo algorithms. \"We make this even more unique and meaningful for users. We are ensuring that whatever medium you get the file, even WhatsApp, you will get the surround experience of the audio when you listen to it,\" said Sarvikas.\n\nDisclaimer: The author is in London at the invite of HMD Global India, which is paying for travel and accommodation.\n\nFor all the latest Technology News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: HMD Global Nokia 8", "id": "9547973", There's also a 3,090mAh battery, which HMD claims will get you more than a full day of usage, complete with support for Quick Charge 3.0.\n\nThere's a USB-C port on the bottom for charging, alongside a 3.5mm headphone jack.\n\nThe Nokia 8, which like its predecessors comes crafted from a single piece of aluminium, has shunned the recent shift towards bezel-less smartphones and comes equipped with a physical home button, which houses a baked-in fingerprint sensor.\n\nThe Nokia 8's standout feature, at least according to HMD Global, is its camera, as it's the first Android-powered Nokia phone to pack Carl Zeiss optics. There's a 13MP dual setup on the rear of the phone, which - much like the camera on the Huawei P10 - pairs RGB and monochrome sensors for better image quality. There's also a 13MP sensor on the front of the phone.\n\nHMD has added what it calls a \"bothie\" mode (ugh) that will activate both the front and rear cameras to capture phones and videos. Unlike the similar functionality found on Samsung smartphones, the Nokia 8 is also capable of broadcasting this video to Facebook or Youtube.\n\nHMD has also added Ozo Audio, which means that much like Nokia's futuristic VR camera, the Nokia 8 will capture 360-degree audio, allowing for it to be broadcast live on streams.\n\nThe Nokia 8 will ship running Android 7.11, and HMD has said that it'll be updated to Android O once it becomes available. A big portion of the 5.00 software update is to the overall master/sub-account system that allows parents to control what kids see and do on the PS4. The overhaul includes a new \"Family on PlayStation Network\" system that aims to be more flexible.\n\nThis new system makes it easier to set up PSN accounts for kids and offers customized parental control settings. Multiple adults can be part of a single family and the Family Manager account can promote another adult inside the family to Parent/Guardian, who is then able to set custom parental controls for children's accounts. Whereas previous parental controls applied all settings to all child accounts, the new system allows for individual settings per child. That means a 6-year-old can be locked to \"E\" rated games only while a 17-year-old can have \"M\" rated games enabled on the same account.\n\nThe \"Favorite Groups\" tab has been replaced with a new \"Custom Lists\" tab within the friends setting, allowing you to create and edit custom friends lists. The goal with that change is to make it easier for users to manage friends and access specific groups. With this setting you can do things like create custom friends lists for your CoD squad and send them all invites at the same time.\n\nUpdates to Broadcasts allows the community owner to bind the community to your broadcast giving a community button on the \"Live from PlayStation\" spectator screen. Other improvements include the ability to share music to Twitter and Facebook via PlayStation Music and to share messages using your PS4 to the social networks. Some, if not all, will make the final cut, with the beta testers tasked with approving or recommending changes before public consumption.\n\nHere are some of the headline features that you can expect to get on your PlayStation 4 or PS4 Pro:\n\nChanges to the family accounts include better handling of master and sub-accounts. A new \"Family on PSN\" system makes it easier to customise parental controls per user and set-up accounts for children. Restricting online access and age ratings can now be done per person.\n\nAn assigned Family Manager controls the accounts, even promoting other adults to parent or guardian status.\n\nYou can now create and edit custom lists of friends, arranging them into specific groups if you want.\n\nCommunities can now be linked to live gameplay broadcasts, where a community button is added to a broadcast so a viewer can jump to and join your community if wanted.\n\nA new setting for PSVR which can turn on spectator comments during a VR experience.\n\nAnd PS4 Pro owners get to broadcast 1080p 60fps video live to Twitch.\n\nYou can now share an individual Spotify or PlayStation Music track via a message. Recipients will be able to listen to the track directly in the message.\n\nYou can now disable notifications pop-ups for movie or TV show viewing. No longer will your viewing experience be interrupted by a pop-up.\n\nYou can also change the colour of the pop-up between white and black.\n\nThe notifications tab can now be seen in the Quick Menu even when you are playing a game. That way you can see the progress of a download, for example.\n\nYou will also be able to \"Leave Party\" from the same menu during a gaming session.\n\nYou can now listen to virtual surround sound when using PSVR. 5.1 and 7.1 virtual surround sound tracks will play through headphones.\n\nA new tournament bracket viewer makes it easier to see matches and results for eliminations {"timeCrawl": "19:31:00", "uri": "711074971", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:54:00Z", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "source": {"title": "newburghgazette.com", "uri": "newburghgazette.com", "id": "18849"}, "url": "http://newburghgazette.com/2017/08/17/ps4-firmware-update-5-00-full-list-of-features-revealed/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369188", "body": "The existing master/sub-account system is being redesigned to be more family friendly, allowing the promotion of accounts to \"parent status\" and each child account can now have individual levels of restriction.\n\nAfter opening registrations last month, Sony has announced in a blog post that invitations are being sent out for successful applicants to the latest system update beta test, detailing key features in the process.\n\nIndividual parental controls will also be available. But with 5.00, all controls (including game age ratings) can be individually attuned for each child. PS4 Pro can now support streaming on Twitch at 1080p 60fps, it's easy to get jealous if still running on a PS4.\n\nManaging a friends list on any console is always a bit of a pain, PS4 is remedying that with the new feature of a \"Custom Lists\" tab.\n\nThis will allow you to create and edit custom lists of your friends and arrange them into specific groups, based on the games you play, or groups of friends you like to hang out with online.\n\nCommunities can now be linked to broadcasts, and PlayStation VR is getting a \"Display Message to Spectators and Spectators\" Comments' option which will show up comments from broadcasts even when you are in VR mode. All a spectator needs to do is click the community button and they can jump right to the community page to check out any details.\n\nFor those who own Sony's Virtual Reality platform, the new update also adds the ability to receive spectator comments during broadcasts. This makes it much easier for VR broadcasters to keep up on comments and communicate with their viewers. With the new update, users will be able to directly send songs and Spotify links via the PlayStation 4's messaging system, in addition to the PlayStation mobile app.\n\nPlayStation VR now supports 5.1ch and 7.1ch virtual surround sound on your headphones when watching Blu-rays and DVDs in Cinematic Mode.\n\nIn addition, if you're part of multiple message groups, you can now easily leave several groups at once. Then you can use that list to easily message and invite your Helldivers squad (hey, Helldivers is still really good) without disturbing your Destiny raid buddies. The new update allows users to turn off message notifications when using apps such as Netflix. This can be enabled by going to the Notifications under Settings.\n\nYou can now turn off message previews on your pop-up notifications. For example, you'll be able to check on download progress and see new party invites.\n\nThe quick menu pop up side bar has also been tweaked, and users will now be able to change the colour from the default black to white, giving the option of contrast for whatever looks better to the user. A Leave Party option has also been added to Quick Menu. The system clock is also promptly displayed in the upper-right corner of the screen when accessing the Quick Menu.\n\nA new bracket viewer has been added that shows full tournament brackets for Single Elimination and Double Elimination tournaments on the console. Making it easier to see current tournament standing.\n\nIt's a hefty update that brings some great features to the PS4 and PS4 Pro only improving upon the changes and features already added and built It features Zeiss optics for the front and rear cameras, and support for recording 360-degree audio.\n\nBut the Nokia 8 doesn't come cheap: the phone is launching for 599 Euros in Europe. That's a little over $700 US, although HMD hasn't yet announced North American prices or release dates for the new phone.\n\nThe Nokia 8 features a dual camera system on the back, with 13MP color and monochrome cameras designed to capture high-contrast images. There's also a 13MP front-facing camera.\n\nWhat's a bit unusual is that the front camera is nearly as good as the one on the back of the phone. While the front-facing camera has just a single lens, it has the same camera module as the rear camera and supports auto-focus.\n\nHMD included a \"bothie\" mode that also lets you capture and combine photos or videos using both the front and rear cameras at the same time. It's a neat, if not entirely original idea... but let's hope the name doesn't catch on.\n\nYou can also stream bothie video to YouTube or Facebook Live in real-time.\n\nThe Nokia 8 should be available starting in September, and it's expected to ship with Android 7.1.\n\nIf you're looking for something (a lot) cheaper, the Nokia 6 recently launched in the US for $230 (or $180 if you buy the Amazon Prime Exclusive model). {"timeCrawl": "23:08:00", "uri": "710586862", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T23:08:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"title": "The Sun", "uri": "thesun.co.uk", "id": "16"}, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/tech/4259592/the-bothie-could-be-the-new-selfie-nokias-new-phone/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "FORGET the selfie - it is all about the \"bothie\" with Nokia's new phone that takes a snap of you AND what you are looking at.\n\nThe firm's new flagship - set to do battle with the new iPhone - uses both the front-facing camera and the rear one at the same time.\n\nAs well as for snaps, the Dual-Sight feature can be used for streaming video live on Facebook and YouTube.\n\nThe idea is to see the person and what they are taking a picture or talking about in a video.\n\nMusic fans might use it when live streaming a concert or festival to pals - to show them singing along, for example.\n\nIt would also be handy for those who do video podcasts - so they can be filmed talking while also showing what they are chatting about.\n\nOr tourists could use when visiting different countries or towns as an alternative to traditional selfies.\n\nA Nokia spokesman said: \"Be less selfie, be more bothie. There are two sides to every story and the Dual-Sight feature of Nokia 8 is designed to help you create and share the full picture.\"\n\nIt is the latest device in the comeback of Nokia phones. The first was a new version of the classic 3310 handset, unveiled in February.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is the first that is designed as a rival to the iPhone and other top-end handsets like Samsung's Galaxy S8.\n\nBoth cameras on the Nokia 8 are rated at 13 MP - meaning each snap is made up of 13 million little dots - which is more than on the iPhone 7.\n\nIt has a 5.3 inch screen and the device is splash proof - though not water resistant like the iPhone and Samsung.\n\nOther features include charging to 80 per cent full in half an hour and speakers that create the impression of surround sound.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is out in September for an expected \u00a3549 in four colours.\n\nNokia was once the biggest phone firm in the world.\n\nBut Nokia struggled after Apple's iPhone and rivals like Samsung became popular and the Finnish firm was forced to sell its phone making business to Microsoft in 2014. {"timeCrawl": "05:47:00", "uri": "710700420", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:47:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"title": "The Indian Express", "uri": "indianexpress.com", "id": "1155"}, "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/technology/mobile-tabs/nokia-maker-mixes-with-apple-samsung-in-new-smartphone-launch-4800442/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "By: Bloomberg | Published:August 17, 2017 11:03 am The Nokia 8 will be available in September and will retail for a global average price of 599 euros (3), HMD said Wednesday. (Image Source: Bloomberg) Nokia 8 launched with dual rear cameras, Snapdragon 835: Full specifications and featuresNokia 8 launched with dual camera and ability to stream from both sides; to be available in India early OctoberNokia 8 full specifications, expected Indian price and everything else to know\n\nFinnish company HMD Global Oy unveiled its latest Nokia-branded smartphone in a first bid to win over Samsung Electronics Co Ltd and Apple Inc. customers.\n\nThe Nokia 8 will be available in September and will retail for a global average price of 599 euros ($703), HMD said Wednesday.\n\nThe company, which started operating in 2016 with an exclusive license for Nokia-branded phones, has so far focused its efforts to revive the Nokia brand on cheaper smartphones and a redesign of the classic Nokia 3310, first sold in 2000. In February HMD unveiled the Nokia 3 and Nokia 5 smartphones, priced at 139 euros ($163) and 189 euros respectively.\n\nJuho Sarvikas, HMD's chief product officer, said now was \"the perfect time\" to introduce the model, which he describes as a flagship product. The phone will feature a \"dual-sight\" photo and video function, in which images from the front and rear cameras will be displayed simultaneously on a split screen. HMD describes the feature as \"less Selfie, more Bothie\".\n\nHMD had chosen to release cheaper models first because 50 percent of global demand was for phones costing between 100 euros and 250 euros, Sarvikas said in an interview. \"We wanted to start there, where we know that we are highly relevant with our proposition. We're very eager to enter the flagship segment as well.\"\n\nAlso read: Nokia 8 first impressions: Sleek design, new camera features and the 'bothie'\n\nThe new device has Zeiss cameras, after HMD said in July that it had signed a partnership with the group, part of the German optics company Carl Zeiss AG.\n\nThe launch comes as Apple prepares to launch a new iPhone and Samsung rolls out its new Galaxy Note 8. Sarvikas said by phone that HMD was \"less concerned about competition; we're here to design for the consumers.\"\n\nDemand for the redesigned 3310 feature phone, unveiled in February, had been \"very strong.\" Sarvikas was unable to share detailed sales figures but said HMD had sold \"millions\" of smartphones and \"tens of millions\" of feature phones - of which the 3310 is just one model.\n\nNokia Oyj sold the handset business to Microsoft Corp. in 2014. In 2016 Microsoft sold it to HMD and FIH Mobile Ltd., a subsidiary of Chinese phone maker Foxconn Technology Group. HMD's Chief Executive Officer Arto Nummela, a former Nokia executive, left the company last month.\n\nFor all the latest Technology News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Apple HMD Global Nokia 8 {"timeCrawl": "10:39:00", "uri": "710825508", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:25:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"title": "http://www.livemint.com/", "uri": "livemint.com", "id": "917"}, "url": "http://www.livemint.com/Technology/NZavwVioZNihPDotWzHjwK/Nokia-8-Just-a-flagship-phone-that-bypasses-substance-for-g.html", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella condemns Charlottesville violence\n\nThe Nokia comeback journey continues, with Finnish company HMD Global unveiling the Nokia 8 flagship Android phone. This, without doubt and while reserving no rights to disagree later, is an attempt to compete with the likes of Samsung's Galaxy S8, Google's current Pixel phones and perhaps even the upcoming Pixel 2 phones and eventually the Apple iPhones as well. Priced at $700 (around Rs45,000), the Nokia 8 will roll out in some countries in September, with the India launch expected in the later months of this year.\n\nA quick look at the Nokia 8's basic specs reveal that it runs the Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 processor, 4GB RAM and will have 64GB internal storage as well as a microSD card slot that will support up to 256GB more storage space. While there is nothing to worry about on the processor front -- since that is the most powerful chip that Nokia could have used at the moment -- there might be some doubts about the RAM and storage space. For flagship phones and even the latest crop of more affordable flagship killer phones such as the OnePlus 5 and the Honor 8 Pro, 6GB RAM is becoming a standard spec which allows for better multi-tasking and more future-proofing. The 64GB storage space isn't flagship-level specification, where 128GB and 256GB storage options are now slowly becoming common. Yes, we might be nit-picking, but the question is -- will you buy the Nokia 8 for the here and now only, or are you looking at specifications that are future proof for your data and app requirements 24 months down the line, perhaps?\n\nThe 5.3-inch (2,560x1,440 resolution) IPS display is spot on in terms of size, and should appeal to the demographic of users who find 5.5-inch display phones a tad too big. There is a Gorilla Glass 5 layer on it too, which adds some amount of durability to it. At a time when Samsung and LG (and perhaps even Apple, with the next iPhone) are switching to the more visually appealing taller (or wider, if you hold the phones sideways) displays, Nokia has remained tethered to the more conventional.\n\nThe Nokia 8 has a 3,090mAh battery, and utilizes Qualcomm's QuickCharge 3.0 fast charging technology.\n\nHMD Global has preloaded the phone with an almost un-customized Android 7.1.1 (Nougat) operating system, and will get the Android O update in the near future too. HMD Global seems committed towards rolling out the security updates for the Nokia 8, and claims that any security updates that Google rolls out (barring the ones that modify the software that works with the modem in the phone) will be released on the same day as updates.\n\nIn terms of design, the Nokia 8 has an all-aluminium chassis, with no room for the potentially more fragile glass backs that are popular with some Android flagship phones. It is 7.9mm at its thickest point, and has a contoured shape that makes it feel even slimmer around the sides. It is splash-proof too, with the IP54 rating -- however, this is a step down from the IP68 ratings that the Samsung Galaxy S8 and the LG G6 offer at the moment.\n\nHowever, the Nokia 8's party piece would perhaps be the Carl Zeiss cameras. There are two 13-megapixel cameras at the back (one is colour, one is monochrome), with optical image stabilization (OIS), have a 1.12um pixel size and f2.0 aperture. The front camera is also 13 megapixels, with similar pixel size and aperture. The company believes that the Nokia 8 will entice consumers with what is now known as the \"bothie\". Essentially, it is supposed to be the evolution of the selfie, and will use both rear and front-facing cameras at the same time to shoot video or photos simultaneously. These can also be shared for live streaming directly on platforms such as Facebook or YouTube. Well, you don't need to be standing next to someone anymore to take a selfie with the Nokia 8, but how much money would you bet on the idea of some neat third-party app offering this feature in your existing Android phone soon enough?\n\nFor audio recording, the Nokia 8 gets to utilize the 360-degree OZO technology used in Nokia's high-end OZO 360 camera -- there are three microphones in the 8, and they each pull 360-degree sound which is then joined together with a 4K video recording using complex algorithms. Whether consumers will genuinely be able to utilize this feature remains up for debate, but maybe the demographic who often claim that a smartphone can become their primary photography and video recording device may find this good enough -- if the camera can take good enough photos, that is.\n\nHMD Global has packed in a full-length copper cooling pipe with a graphite shield to dissipate system heat across the full body of the phone. It is designed to pull the heat away from the Snapdragon 835 chip, with the hope that it'll be able to perform better for longer, even under heavy workloads. It is a bit perplexing though, because no phone running the Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 chip (this includes the OnePlus 5, Sony Xperia XZ Premium and the HTC U11) has ever suffered from over-heating issues even when really stressed with the latest games, extensive camera use and intense multi-tasking. Could this be the complex algorithms of Nokia's camera and the bothie gimmicks that require this counter measure?", "id": "9665475", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Nokia 8: Just a flagship phone that bypasses substance for gimmicks?", "image": "http://www.livemint.com/rf/Image-621x414/LiveMint/Period2/2017/08/18/Photos/Processed/Nokia8-k9TG--621x414@LiveMint.jpg", The Nokia 3 and Nokia 5 were the company's offline-exclusive handsets while the Nokia 6 will be available from Amazon India starting August 23. It offers 2GB RAM, 16GB storage and supports expandable storage up to 128GB via SD card slot. It's these people who have inspired us to craft a flagship smartphone which perfectly balances premium design, an outstanding experience and powerful performance,\" said Juho Sarvikas, Chief Product Officer of HMD Global.\n\nNokia 8 enables its users livestream videos on social feeds such as Facebook and YouTube using its Dual-Sight feature that uses both the front and rear cameras simultaneously in a split screen visual for both photos and videos.\n\nThe front and rear-facing cameras on the Nokia 8 have been co-developed with ZEISS optics for 'bothie'. Users also get unlimited photo and video uploads to Google Photos.\n\nIt is the world's first smartphone to broadcast live with both the front and back cameras simultaneously. (Image: nokia.com)\n\nNokia 8 is also the first smartphone to feature Nokia OZO Audio. OZO spatial 360 degrees audio brings an immersive experience to 4K video.\n\nThe phone features Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 chip, offers pure, secure and updated Android experience and is Qualcomm Quick Charge 3.0 compatible for 3,090 mAh battery.\n\nThe device comes with a lightweight, water, sweat, and dust-proof premium Nokia 'Active Wireless Headset'.\n\nIt comes with a 4GB RAM and 64GB storage that can be extended up to 256GB. It has a 5.3-inch IPS LCD QHD display and is protected by Corning Gorilla Glass 5.\n\nThe primary camera has two lenses -- 13MP (Colour + OIS) and 13MP (Mono) with dual tone flash. The 13MP front facing camera has Phase-detection autofocus (PDAF).\n\nThe Nokia 5 smartphone, already released in India, is available in retail stores at Rs 12,499.\n\nThe Nokia 6 has received over {"timeCrawl": "19:06:00", "uri": "710496683", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T19:06:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"title": "Mashable", "uri": "mashable.com", "id": "17380"}, "url": "http://mashable.com/2017/08/16/nokia-8-flagship-phone-review-bothie/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Nokia is betting big with its first flagship phone.\n\nAs a series of leaks previously reported, the Nokia 8, just released by Finnish startup HMD, is a seriously impressive, top-end device whose specs put it on par with other Android flagships such as the Samsung Galaxy S8 and the OnePlus 5.\n\nHMD's aim is clear: leverage the Nokia brand to aggressively target millennials with an experience-oriented, social media-savvy phone.\n\nFeaturing a vertically lined-up dual-rear camera with Zeiss-branded optics, the phone has a sleek, compact style which reflects its Scandinavian roots.\n\nAnd with a new feature called \"Dual Sight,\" you can take photos simultaneously from the front and rear cameras to create a split-screen visual. Nokia dubs this not a selfie, but a \"Bothie\" -- wonder if the term will catch on?\n\nThe phone has a fingerprint scanner-home button combo on the front and OZO high-dynamic range audio recording.\n\nNotably for Nokia brand fans though, there's no Snake game to while away the time between bothies.\n\nThe Nokia 8 also has a 13-megapixel camera on the front which allows Dual-Sight video to be live-streamed natively and in real-time to social media.\n\nThe Dual Sight feature simultaneously harnesses front and rear cameras for both photos and videos.\n\n\"There are two sides to every story and the Dual-Sight feature of Nokia 8 is designed to help you create and share the full picture,\" says Nokia, which has created the slogan, \"Be less Selfie, be more Bothie.\"\n\nBuilt on a single block of aluminium, Nokia 8's body is 4.6mm thin at the edge and just 7.3mm slim on average.\n\nThe screen is slightly curved at the edges, but it's not one of those new ultra-wide screens that adorn most high-profile flagships these days.\n\n\"It's a phone for everyone, but focused on the next generations -- millennials and creators -- who are sharing every day their life great moments and experiences,\" said Pekka Rantala, HMD CEO.\n\nThe Nokia 8 runs on a Snapdragon 835 platform, Qualcomm's top-end chip, with a 1.90GHz CPU speed, 4GB of memory, and an Adreno 540 GPU.\n\nThe 5.3-inch, super-bright display has a resolution of 2560 x 1440 pixels and a pixel density of 559.\n\nNokia 8 uses OZO's Dolby surround audio technology and allows you to shoot 4K high-quality videos.\n\nMashable tested the audio performance on a preset video and it's impressively clear and crisp, with well-defined highs and nuances.\n\n\"We know that fans are creating and sharing live content more than ever before, with millions of photos and videos shared every minute on social media,\" said Juho Sarvikas, Chief Product Officer of HMD Global.\n\n\"People are inspired by the content they consume and are looking for new ways to create their own. It's these people who have inspired us to craft a flagship smartphone which perfectly balances premium design, an outstanding experience and powerful performance.\"\n\nThe handset will be available in four colours: Polished Blue, Tempered Blue, Steel, and a very daring Polished Copper which has attracted a lot of attention in the past few months.\n\nIt will be available at a global average retail "body": "HMD Global is hoping a reinvention of the selfie will help the Nokia brand regain its place in the forefront of the mobile market.\n\nIts first flagship phone - the Nokia 8 - features the \"bothie\".\n\nUsing both the forward and rear-facing cameras, photographers will be able to take a picture of themselves at the same time as whatever they are pointing their phones towards.\n\nWatch: Nokia 8 'Bothie' phone is here (CNBC)\n\nThe Dual-Sight technology allows for video to be live-streamed to friends and to social feeds including to Facebook and YouTube.\n\nThe headline innovation of the Android-running device comes at the Finnish company, HMD Global, a private equity-backed firm led by former Nokia employees, attempts to reforge the brand's popularity.\n\nA retro revamp of Nokia's famous 3310 handset went on sale in May, but in financial terms did not come close to challenge the titanic popularity of Apple, Samsung and China's Huawei devices.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is the ninth mobile device made by HMD Global, which has acquired the rights to make and sell phones under the Nokia brand.\n\nA number of features are packed into its 7.3mm body which is milled from aluminium, including Qualcomm's Snapdragon 835 processor, 4GB of RAM and 64GB of internal storage - which can be extended via the MicroSD card slot.\n\nThe Nokia 8 is set to be released in September with an It's these people who have inspired us to craft a flagship smartphone which perfectly balances premium design, an outstanding experience and powerful performance,\" said Juho Sarvikas, Chief Product Officer of HMD Global.\n\nNokia 8 enables its users livestream videos on social feeds such as Facebook and YouTube using its Dual-Sight feature that uses both the front and rear cameras simultaneously in a split screen visual for both photos and videos.\n\nThe front and rear-facing cameras on the Nokia 8 have been co-developed with ZEISS optics for 'bothie'. Users also get unlimited photo and video uploads to Google Photos.\n\nNokia 8 is also the first smartphone to feature Nokia OZO Audio. OZO spatial 360 degrees audio brings an immersive experience to 4K video.\n\nThe phone features Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 chip, offers pure, secure and updated Android experience and is Qualcomm Quick Charge 3.0 compatible for 3,090 mAh battery.\n\nThe device comes with a lightweight, water, sweat, and dust-proof premium Nokia 'Active Wireless Headset'.\n\nIt comes with a 4GB RAM and 64GB storage that can be extended up to 256GB. It has a 5.3-inch IPS LCD QHD display and is protected by Corning Gorilla Glass 5.\n\nThe primary camera has two lenses -- 13MP (Colour + OIS) and 13MP (Mono) with dual tone flash. The 13MP front facing camera has Phase-detection autofocus (PDAF).\n\nThe Nokia 5 smartphone, already released in India, is available in retail stores at Rs 12,499.\n\nThe Nokia 6 has received over All controls can be individually controlled for each child account.\n\nSony is adding a new \"Custom Lists\" tab on the Friends screen in place of the existing \"Favorite Groups\" tab. {"timeCrawl": "22:50:00", "uri": "710581430", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T17:33:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"title": "PCMag India", "uri": "in.pcmag.com", "id": "19060"}, "url": "http://in.pcmag.com/nokia/116246/news/hmd-global-launches-its-flagship-nokia-8-with-a-dual-sight-c", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "The phone will be available in global markets this September and is expected to land in India by October.\n\nEarlier in the year, the iconic Nokia name resurfaced on smartphones thanks to a little known company called HMD Global. It launched the Nokia 6 to great fanfare in China and then at MWC in February, the company launched an entire portfolio of products including the Nokia 3, Nokia 5, the global version of the Nokia 6 and even a new version of 3310 feature phone. These phones have started propping up in markets around the world, including India. However, now is the time for a halo device and that's what the new Nokia 8 is. This phone will be available in global markets this September and is expected to land in India by October.\n\nLaunched at an event in London, the Nokia 8 is an attempt by HMD Global to showcase that it has the ability to produce a flagship class device which is innovative. This is the company's halo device for the year and its hardware is proof of the pudding.\n\n\"Nokia 8 is flagship in design, imaging and performance,\" said Juho Sarvikas, HMD Global's chief product officer at a press briefing with the media.\n\nThe Nokia 8 has the latest Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 processor, 4GB RAM and a gorgeous 5.3-inch LCD display with Corning Gorilla Glass 5 with a quad HD resolution and impressive brightness levels of up to 700 nits.\n\nHMD Global is focusing on real world usage here on this phone. It says that 4GB RAM is all what a flagship Android phone needs, something which has been proven on devices like the Google Pixel and the Samsung Galaxy S8. It also comes with an evolved antenna design adapted from the Nokia 5 and for heat management the phone has a copper pipe inside.\n\nThe phone has a series 6000 aluminium frame which was seen before on the Nokia 6. However, it is being offered in some unique colours -- polished blue, polished copper, tempered blue and steel; so there aren't any standard black and white colours here. It also has a certain degree of splash resistance.\n\nIt forgoes some new niceties that are becoming common on high end smartphone though. For instance, its display makes no pretensions about being edge-to-edge, it is nice but it is no Samsung Galaxy S8 which is fine.\n\nThe bigger deal is in its camera system. On the back HMD Global has rekindled an old partnership again. This phone has dual 13-megapixel sensors which have Carl Zeiss optics. Back in the day, Nokia phones were known to have Carl Zeiss lenses and boom we have that again. Even the dual camera system on the device is an interesting one as it doesn't use the widely adopted wide angle lens and telephoto lens combination. Instead, this phone, like the Huawei P10, has an RGB sensor and a monochrome sensor which allows for greater detailing in low light, better colour output and a truer looking image. The primary camera system also comes with stabilised lens which further improves low-light shooting especially when making videos. It also comes with a laser auto focus.\n\nEven on the selfie front, the phone packs a generous 13-megapixel shooter and all things considered when one uses the HMD Global camera app, shooting pictures from this device is a breeze. In fact, HMD Global has gone to great lengths with the front camera too as it uses the very same sensor as the RGB one on the rear and also has Carl Zeiss optics. This also means the front camera can also shoot in 4K.\n\nThe camera technology is really interesting as it packs in something HMD Global calls a dual sight mode which essentially allows the user to engage all the cameras at the same time offering a view from a standard and selfie perspective. Some HMD Global folks referred to this to as a 'Bothie.' This is an interesting feature and as Qualcomm's chipset doesn't support this out of the box, HMD Global had to work closely with Qualcomm to make this feature happen.\n\nOne of the big announcements as a part of this launch is that the Nokia Ozo audio technology is making its way to the device. HMD Global says that this has an inherent advantage over standard stereo and the phone packs multiple microphones to ensure great audio capture. In addition, Juho Sarvikas explained that when a traditional video is uploaded to social networks and platforms like YouTube the metadata for the encoding is lost. On the Nokia 8 that data is embedded and when videos from the phone are uploaded, their audio quality will be vastly superior.\n\n\"We have high dynamic range microphones and then encoded in Ozo audio algorithm\", said Sarvikas to PCMag India.\n\nLive streaming has been integrated on the stock camera app which borrows many cues from the erstwhile pro camera app Nokia used to make for its Lumia Windows Phones. This will allow users to stream videos directly to Facebook and YouTube. You can even live stream using all cameras offering the dual sight perspective. HMD Global hasn't integrated other services like Instagram but it says it is already working on improving the feature like adding support for multiple accounts.\n\nSome usual things are also part of the package like a front mounted fingerprint scanner, 4G LTE, USB Type-C, a 3,090mAh battery, and fast charging. It will be offered in a 64GB model and microSD card expansion besides a possible dual SIM model for open markets like India.\n\nThis phone runs on Android 7.1 Nougat completely bereft of any manufacturer led modifications and the latest Google security patch mimicking an experience one finds on the critically acclaimed Pixel smartphone that Google makes.\n\nHMD Global is confident that this would be one of the fastest ways to experience Android O. \"We are at a very advanced stage with the development of Android O,\" Sarvikas revealed highlighting that this phone will be one the first ones to get the update once Google officially releases the final build of the software.\n\nAt around around 599 euros this will be an expensive phone which will go on sale in India later next month for more than Rs 40,000.\n\nDisclaimer: HMD Global paid for the writers travel and stay to London to cover the event", "id": "9577969", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "HMD Global launches its flagship Nokia 8 with a dual sight camera system and OZO audio", "image": "http://sm.pcmag.com/pcmag_in/photo/default/nokia-8-1_jddu.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "concepts": [{"location": {"label": {"eng": "People's Republic of China"}, "type": "country"}, "score": 4, "id": "47", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China", "label": {"eng": {"timeCrawl": "10:20:00", "uri": "710816112", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:20:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"title": "Metro.co.uk", "uri": "metro.co.uk", "id": "218"}, "url": "http://metro.co.uk/2017/08/17/nokias-new-flagship-phone-set-to-revolutionise-selfies-6858649/", "eventUri": "eng-3365057", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3365057", "body": "Nokia's new flagship phone set to revolutionise selfies Tanveer Mann for Metro.co.ukThursday 17 Aug 2017 10:52 am Share this article with Facebook Share this article with Twitter Share this article with Google Plus Share this article with Whatsapp Share this article through email Share this article through sms\n\nNokia has launched its first flagship Android smartphone - the Nokia 8 - and it's set to revolutionalise how we take selfies.\n\nApple's iPhone 8 faces serious challenge from leaked Nokia 8 smartphone\n\nThe new handset, which has been designed to compete with the iPhone 7 and Samsung's Galaxy S8, will cost \u00a3546 and comes with split screen camera feature called Dual Sight.\n\nThis first-of-its-kind feature combines a photo or video from the front and rear-facing cameras at the same time, so that you end up with something Nokia is calling a 'Bothie'.\n\nThe Dual-Sight feature can also be used for streaming video live on Facebook and YouTube.\n\nThe point of it is so that you can see the person and what they are talking about in a video.\n\nSo, for example, tourists could use it when visiting different countries or towns as an alternative to traditional selfies.\n\nMORE: There's a new Nokia Android smartphone - and it's just \u00a3119\n\nA Nokia spokesman said: 'Be less selfie, be more bothie. There are two sides to every story and the Dual-Sight feature of Nokia 8 is designed to help you create and share the full picture.'\n\nPolice are using prams to catch people parking illegally\n\nNokia is now under licence to HMD Global, a Finnish start-up, which sparked the firm's revival earlier this year with the launch of three mid-range Android phones - the Nokia 3,5 and 6, as well as a revamped version of the 17-year-old 3310.\n\nThe new phone also has spatial audio technology previously only used in Nokia's high-end OZO 360 camera, which can play back sound in multiple directions, imitating how it was captured during recording.\n\nHMD Global confirmed the phone will go on sale in 'early September' and said the device was aimed at social media users and video creators.\n\nHMD chief product officer Juho Sarvikas said: 'We know that fans are creating and sharing live content more than ever before, with millions of photos and videos shared every minute on social media.\n\n'People are inspired by the content they consume and are looking for new ways to create their own.\n\n'It's these people who have inspired us to craft a flagship smartphone which perfectly balances premium design, an outstanding experience and powerful performance.'\n\nNokia and HMD Global's unveiling comes a week before Samsung is due to announce their next Note smartphone, the first since the Note 7 was discontinued last year over battery fires and safety fears.\n\nThe next iPhone, marking 10 years since the device first launched, is also expected to be announced in September.\n\nMORE: Malala Yousafzai is going to Oxford University after passing her A-Levels\n\nMORE: Man's extreme cramp looks like alien trying to burst through his leg", "id": "9661768",
